GENERAL:
Court convened to release orders and hear oral arguments
October 1, 1979 and adjourned October 6, 1980__
Civiletti, Benjamin R., Attorney General, presented _____
Douglas, J., Columbia University conferred honorary LLD
degree at Supreme Court on December 6, 1979 (First time
since 1861 Trustees went off campus to confer degree).
Douglas J., died January 19, 1980. Announcement of death
by Burger, C.J. Buried in Arlington Cemetery near
Holmes, J.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1979
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
1
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"I have the honor to announce that the October 1979 Term of the
Supreme Court of the United States is now convened."
Mr. Solicitor General McCree presented the Honorable Benjamin R.
Civiletti, Attorney General of the United States.
The Chief Justice said:
"Mr. Attorney General, the Court welcomes you to the performance
of the important duties which devolve upon you as the chief law
officer of the Government, and as an officer of this Court. Your com-
mission will be recorded by the Clerk."
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-1671. Dodson Insurance Group, appellant, v. James A.
Maloney, Judge of the District Court of New Mexico, Second Judicial
District. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Mexico. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-1833. Nadine O. Monroe, appellant, v. Floyd R. Monroe, Jr.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Connecticut. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-6645. Albert H. Carter, appellant, v. Texas. Appeal from
the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
310-278-79- -1

2
MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1979
No. 78-6743. William Ronald Welch, appellant, v. Lee C. Falke,
Prosecuting Attorney, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Ohio.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers.
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied.
No. 78-6765. Millicent Linden, appellant, v. Harper & Row Pub-
lishers, Inc. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 786768. Eli Raitport, appellant, v. Edward Lyons, Superin-
tendent of Prisons of Philadelphia. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of Pennsylvania, Eastern District. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-6771. Edward Wayland, appellant, v. Aaron Harkaway.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied.
No. 78-6875. Millicent Linden, appellant, v. Nathan A. Shore et al.
Appeal from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New
York, First Judicial Department. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-6876. Edward Wayland, appellant, v. Harold Moore et
al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the First
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-6896. Anna Berenholz, appellant, v. Nathan Berenholz.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.
No. 78–6904. John Kalenian, appellant, v. Patricia Kalenian.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 79–5072. Johnny Garcia, appellant, v. Arizona. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division One. The appeal is dis-

MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1979
80
3
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the ap-
peal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 79–5100. Margarite Petrillo, appellant, v. Pasquale Spatola.
Appeal from the Superior Court of New Jersey, Chancery Division,
Middlesex County. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78–1710. Barton Dean Ford, appellant, v. Texas. Appeal
from the Comal County, Texas, Court-at-law. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78–1808. John Conway et al appellants, v. The Hospital
Corporation of America et al. Appeal from the Court of Civil Ap-
peals of Texas, Sixth Supreme Judicial District. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78–1812. Heather Elizabeth O'Donnell et al., appellants, v.
State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Michigan. The appeal is dismissed for want.
of a substantial federal question.
No. 78–1828. Guy Sparks et al., appellants, v. Robert M. Parker,
etc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Alabama. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78-1854. Lennie B. Warren and Everette R. Warren, ap-
pellants, v. Sun Oil Company. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of
Oklahoma, Division 2. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 78-1936. Francis E. Rinehart, appellant, v. Association of
the Bar of the City of New York. Appeal from the Appellate Divi-
sion of the Supreme Court of New York, First Judicial Department.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question..
No. 78-6704. Charlotte Fince, appellant, v. Ann Klein, Commis-
sioner, Department of Human Services, et al. Appeal from the Su-
preme Court of New Jersey. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 78-6911. Willie Jerry Lamar, appellant, v. Georgia. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
No. 79-13. Antoinette Foster, appellant, v. County School Board
of Prince William County. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Vir-
ginia. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.

4
MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1979
No. 79-34. Ford E. Stinson, appellant, v. Louisiana State Bar
Association. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 79-38. Leola Perry, Administratrix of the Estate of James
Herschel Perry, appellant, v. Kalamazoo State Hospital. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Michigan. The appeal is dismissed for want of
a substantial federal question.
No. 79-49. James T. M. Prest, appellant, v. Robert L. Herbst, etc.,
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Minnesota. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 79–90. James E. Skelton, appellant, v. City of Birmingham.
Appeal from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Alabama. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 79–126. Charles R. Dudley and Delores S. Dudley, appellants,
v. Nebraska State Bank. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Nebraska.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 79–146. Rudolph Slagle et al., appellants, v. Luther Parker
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Alabama. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 79–164. Spiegel, Inc., appellant, v. South Dakota, etc., et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of South Dakota. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 79–5098. Ronald Wilson, appellant, v. Ohio. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Ohio. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 78–5099. John D. Hinkle, Jr., appellant, v. Ohio. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Cuyahoga County. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 79-5165. William Postell, appellant, v. Texas. Appeal from
the County Court at Law, El Paso County, Texas. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78-1780. Gentry Crowell, Secretary of State of Tennessee,
et al., appellants, v. Richard Mader et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court for the
Middle District of Tennessee with directions to dismiss the cause as
moot.
No. 78-1882. Benson A. Wolman et al., appellants, v. Franklin B.
Walter et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Southern District of Ohio. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Brennan
and Mr. Justice Stewart dissent.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1979
5
No. 78–1937. Metro Broadcasting Company, Inc., appellant, v.
Secretary of the Treasury of Puerto Rico. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Puerto Rico. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 78-6750. William E. Conrad, appellant, v. John K. Regan,
United States District Judge, et al. Appeal from the United States.
District Court for the District of Columbia. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction.
No. 78–1940. James E. O'Connor et al., appellants, v. San Fran-
cisco Police Commission et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of
California, First Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr.
Justice Marshall would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for
oral argument.
No. 78-6413. Berthe Letourneau, appellant, v. Patricia Roberts
Harris, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Southern District of
New York. The appeal is dismissed as untimely. Mr. Justice Blackmun
would affirm judgment.
No. 79–130. John E. Behnke, appellant, v. Committee on Pro-
fessional Ethics and Conduct of the Iowa State Bar Association.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Iowa. The appeal is dismissed.
for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Brennan would
note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-6659. Johnny L. Blake, petitioner, v. Vinson F. Thompson,
Warden. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further consideration in light of Jackson v. Virginia, 443 U.S.
(1979).
No. 78-6840. Roger H. Corley, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the District of Columbia Court of
Appeals. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the District of Columbia Court of Appeals for fur-
ther consideration in light of the position presently asserted by the
Solicitor General in his memorandum filed August 31, 1979. Mr. Jus-
tice Rehnquist and Mr. Justice Stevens dissent.
No. 79-110. Kentucky, petitioner, v. George Edward Martin. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Kentucky.

6
MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1979
Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals of Kentucky for further considera-
tion in light of Kentucky v. Whorton, 441 U.S.
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
(1979).
No. A-1060, O. T. 1978. John Nash et al., applicants, v. Delbert
Chandler et al. Application for stay or to vacate injunction, addressed
to Mr. Justice Brennan and referred to the Court, denied.
No. A-1134, 0. T. 1978. Pennhurst State School and Hospital et
al., applicants, v. Terri Lee Halderman et al. Application for stay of
judgment and order of United States District Court for the Eastern
District of Pennsylvania, dated March 5, 1979, addressed to the Chief
Justice and referred to the Court, denied.
No. A-12. Clyde D. Chaffin, applicant, v. Carl Thomas, Sheriff of
Dallas County, Texas. Application for stay and bail, addressed to
Mr. Justice Brennan and referred to the Court, denied.
No. A-71. Remon Bustamante Carlos et al., applicants, v. United
States et al. Application for injunction, addressed to Mr. Justice White
and referred to the Court, denied.
No. A-95. Retail Store Employees Union, etc., et al., applicants,
v. United Food and Commercial Workers Internl. Union, et al. Ap-
plication for stay pending appeal to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit, addressed to Mr. Justice Brennan
and referred to the Court, denied.
No. A-133. Florence M. Evans, etc., et al., applicants, v. Secretary
of Army et al. Application for an injunction, addressed to Mr. Justice
White and referred to the Court, denied.
No. A-172. Kirk B. Lenhard and George E. Franzen, Clark County
Deputy Public Defenders, individually and as next friends acting on
behalf of Jesse Walter Bishop, applicants, v. Charles Wolff, Warden,
Nevada State Prison System, et al. Application for stay of execution
of sentence of death presented to Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and by him
stayed to and including October 1, 1979, and referred to the Court,
denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom
Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
No. D-153. In the Matter of Disbarment of J. Jerome Olitt. Dis-
barment entered.
No. 5, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
California. Report of Special Master received and ordered filed. Ex-

MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1979
7
ceptions, if any, with supporting briefs to the report may be filed by
the parties within 45 days. Reply briefs, if any, to such exceptions may
be filed within 30 days. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this order.
No. 9, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Louisiana et al. Supplemental Report of Special Master received and
ordered filed. Exceptions, if any, with supporting briefs to the report
may be filed by the parties within 45 days. Reply briefs, if any, to such
exceptions may be filed within 30 days. Mr. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. 81, Original. Commonwealth of Kentucky, plaintiff, v. State
of Indiana et al. Report of Special Master received and ordered filed.
Exceptions, if any, with supporting briefs to the report may be filed
by the parties within 30 days. Reply briefs, if any, to such exceptions
may be filed within 30 days.
No. 78-119. Washington et al., petitioners, v. United States et al.
Upon consideration of motion of State of Washington for modifica-
tion of opinion of this Court, memorandum filed by the respondent
tribes, memorandum filed by the United States and the reply thereto, it
is ordered that footnote 16 of opinion be modified as follows:
"A factual dispute exists on the question of what percentage of the
fish in the case area actually passes through Indian fishing areas and
is therefore subject to the District Court's allocations. In the absence
of
any relevant findings by the courts below, we are unable to express
any view on the matter."
No. 78–160. Roy Tibbals Wilson et al., petitioners, v. Omaha Indian
Tribe et al.; and
No. 78–161. Iowa et al., petitioners, v. Omaha Indian Tribe et al.
Motion of Maine et al. for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, granted.
Motion for modification of opinion denied. Mr. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of these motions.

Huff et al.; and
No. 78-1006. Harold R. Brown, Secretary of Defense, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Albert Edwards Glines. Motion of Solicitor General to
consolidate cases for oral argument denied.

of the Colville Indian Reservation et al. Motion of The All Indian
Pueblo Council, Inc. for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.

lotted additional five minutes for oral argument.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1979
9
Motion of Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argument,
as amicus curiae, granted. Ten additional minutes alloted for oral
argument and time allocated as follows: petitioners-20 minutes, Soli-
citor General-15 minutes, respondents-35 minutes.
No. 78-1651. Seatrain Shipbuilding Corporation, et al., petitioners,
v. Shell Oil Company, et al. Motion of Solicitor General for addi-
tional time for oral argument granted and five additional minutes are
allotted for that purpose. The non-federal respondents allotted an
additional five minutes for oral argument.
No. 78-1789. Arkansas Louisiana Gas Company, petitioner, v.
Frank J. Hall et al. Solicitor General invited to file a brief in this
case expressing the views of the United States. Mr. Justice Stewart
took no part in the consideration or decision of this matter.
No. 78–1840. City of Rome et al., appellants, v. United States et
al. Motion of Pacific Legal Foundation for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, granted.
No. 78–5937. Ventura E. Ybarra, appellant, v. Illinois. Motion of
Ralph Ruebner, Esquire, to permit Alan D. Goldberg, Esquire, to
present oral argument, pro hac vice, granted.
No. 78–6020. Michael M. Busic, petitioner, v. United States. Motion
for appointment of counsel granted and it is ordered that Samuel J.
Reich, Esquire, of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, is appointed to serve as
counsel for petitioner in this case; and
No. 78–6029. Anthony LaRocca, Jr., petitioner, v. United States.
Motion for appointment of counsel granted and it is ordered that
Michael A. Litman, Esquire, of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, is
appointed to serve as counsel for petitioner in this case.
No. 79–206. Manley Investment Company, petitioner, v. Thomas W.
Garland, Inc., et al. Application for stay of proceedings in the United
States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri, addressed
to Mr. Justice Rehnquist and referred to the Court, denied.
No. 79–231. Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company, peti-
tioner, v. Public Utilities Commission of California et al.; and
No. 79–232. General Telephone Company of California, petitioner,
v. Public Utilities Commission of California et al. Applications for
stay, addressed to Mr. Justice Brennan and referred to the Court,
denied.
No. 79-444. Gonzalo Fernos-Lopez, petitioner, v. United States
District Court for the District of Puerto Rico. Application for stay
of proceedings, addressed to the Chief Justice and referred to the
Court, denied.

APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 79–45. Gerald A. Lewis, Comptroller of the State of Florida,
etc., appellant, v. BT Investment Managers, Inc., et al. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the Northern District of Florida.
In this case probable jurisdiction noted.
No. 79-134. Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc.,
appellant, v. Public Service Commission of New York. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of New York. In this case probable jurisdiction
noted.
No. 78-1604. Central Machinery Company, appellant, v. Arizona
State Tax Commission. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Arizona.
In this case probable jurisdiction noted. Case set for oral argument
in tandem with No. 78-1177, White Mountain Apache Tribe v.
Bracker.

to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Petition for writ of certiorari

this motion and petition.

actions of single Justices during the summer recess, pursuant to the
Order of this Court entered on the twenty-fourth day of May 1971:

No. 78–740. Cecil D. Andrus, Secretary of the Interior, et al., ap-
pellants, v. L. Douglas Allard et al. Argued by Mrs. Harriet S. Shapiro
for the appellants and By Mr. John P. Akolt, III, for the appellees.

Ms. Kathryn A. Oberly for the respondent.

Broussard, petitioners, v. Vermilion Corporation. Argued by Mr.

for the respondent.

Diverson Ford et al. Argued by Mr. E. D. Vickery for the petitioners
and by Mr. Peter Buscemi, pro hac vice, by special leave of Court, for
the respondents.

135
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

310-278-79-12



(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1979
137
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Justice.
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 78-6932. Richard Earl Pilon, petitioner, v. Donald E. Borden-
kircher, Warden. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Motion for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States District
Court for the Western District of Kentucky so that it may consider the
petitioner's application for habeas corpus in light of Jackson v. Vir-
ginia, 443 U.S. (1979).
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78–6773. Herman Thomas, appellant, v. New York. Appeal
from the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court of New York, First
Judicial Department. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substan-
tial federal question. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White with
whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
No. 79-251. Earl L. Sappington, appellant, v. Paul R. Beckert,
etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the East-
ern District of Pennsylvania. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction.
☐ No. 79-329. Ralph J. Skinkiss, appellant, v. Owens-Corning
Fiberglas Corp. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Lucas
County. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 79–5103. Robert Carey, appellant, v. New York State Human
Rights Appeal Board et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New-
York. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
310-278-79-13

138
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1979
No. 79–5189. Jay Clair Colver, appellant, v. California. Appeal
from the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 79–5101. Margarite Petrillo, appellant, v. Township of Wood-
bridge. Appeal from the Superior Court of New Jersey, Chancery
Division, Middlesex County. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 79-5174. Eli Raitport, appellant, v. Provident National Bank.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.
No. 79-5217. Samuel Corrado, appellant, v. Seth K. Gifford. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Rhode Island. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the ap-
peal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 79-5198. David Lee Powell, appellant, v. W. J. Estelle, Jr.,
Director, Texas Department of Corrections. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Texas. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari denied. Dissenting statement by Mr.
Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79–274. Robert Moye, petitioner, v. Connecticut. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Connecticut. Petition
for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Supreme Court of Connecticut for further consideration in
light of Sanstrom v. Montana, 442 U.S. (1979).
-

No. A-219. Anthony Provenzano, applicant, v. United States. Ap-
plication for bail pending appeal, addressed to Mr. Justice Brennan
and referred to the Court, denied.
No. A–231. Denise Hudson, applicant, v. Texas Parks & Wildlife
Department et al. Application for injunction pending appeal, ad-
dressed to Mr. Justice Brennan and referred to the Court, denied.
No. A-277. National Railroad Passenger Corporation, applicant,
v. Tony P. Hall et al. Motion to vacate stay granted by the Chief Jus-
tice on September 30, 1979, denied.
No. D–162. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Joseph Turner.
Disbarment entered.

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1979
139
No. D-164. In the Matter of Disbarment of Thomas E. Macurdy.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-165. In the Matter of Disbarment of Norman Shine Roth-
bart. Disbarment entered.
No. D-167. In the Matter of Disbarment of Arthur A. Reiser, Jr.,
Disbarment entered.
No. D-170. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert Baer Cohen.
It is ordered that Robert Baer Cohen, of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why
he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-171. In the Matter of the Disbarment of James Leon Gar-
cia, Jr. It is ordered that James Leon Garcia, Jr., of Los Angeles,
California, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and
that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show
cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this
Court.
No. D–172. In the Matter of Disbarment of Maurice Albert Bendes.
It is ordered that Maurice Albert Bendes, of Lawrence, New York,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requuiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-173. In the Matter of Disbarment of Eugenio Cornier
Salls. It is ordered that Eugenio Cornier Salls, of New York, New
York, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-174. In the Matter of Disbarment of Daniel J. Spooner.
It is ordered that Daniel J. Spooner, of New York, New York, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-175. In the Matter of Disbarment of Sidney Feldshuh.
It is ordered that Sidney Feldshuh, of Scarsdale, New York, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-176. In the Matter of Disbarment of David A. Pravda.
It is ordered that David A. Pravda, of New York, New York, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 78-1933. Steven H. Montgomery, etc., petitioner, v. Century
Laminating, Ltd. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit granted.
No. 79–192. New York Gaslight Club, Inc., et al., petitioners,
v. Cidni Carey. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit granted.
No. 78-6621. Gilbert Franklin Beck, petitioner, v. Alabama.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Alabama granted,
limited to the question presented by the Court: May a sentence of
death constitutionally be imposed after a jury verdict of guilt of a
capital offense, when the jury was not permitted to consider a verdict
of guilt of a lesser included non-capital offense, and when the evidence
would have supported such a verdict?
No. 78-6899. Robert Franklin Godfrey, petitioner, v. Georgia.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia granted,
limited to the question presented by the Court: In affirming the im-
position of the death sentence in this case, has the Georgia Supreme
Court adopted such a broad and vague construction of Georgia Code
Ann. § 27-2534.1(b) (7) (specifying certain aggravating circum-
stances) as to violate the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments to the
United States Constitution?
No. 79-5010. Alphonse Bifulco, petitioner, v. United States. Mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit granted.

(1979).

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1979
157
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 78–1602. United States et al., petitioners, v. Benmar Trans-
port & Leasing Corp., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Petition for
writ of certiorari granted, judgment reversed, and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79-349. E. I. Malone, etc., appellant, v. White Motor Corpora-
tion, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. Judgment affairmed. Allied Structural Steel Co. v.
Spannaus, 438 U.S. 234 (1978). Mr. Justice Blackman took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 79-5244. Clara Newkirk Dawson appellant, v. Reuben H. Daw-
son. Appeal from the District of Columbia Court of Appeals. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-90. Paul Samuel Taylor, applicant, v. United States. Ap-
plication for bail, addressed to Mr. Justice Marshall and referred to
the Court, denied.
No. A-123. Peter Charles Shelton, applicant, v. United States. Ap-
plication for bail, addressed to Mr. Justice Marshall and referred to
the Court, denied.
No. D-177. In the Matter of Disbarment of Paul E. Panek. It is
ordered that Paul E. Panek of Belton, Missouri, be suspended from the
practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be dis-
barred from the practice of law in this Court.
310-278-79-16

158
MONDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1979
No. D-178. In the Matter of Disbarment of Conrad P. Smith. It is
ordered that Conrad P. Smith of Washington, D.C., be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable with-
in forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be dis-
barred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-179. In the Matter of Disbarment of Joe Merrill Kyle. It is
ordered that Joe Merrill Kyle of Silver Spring, Maryland, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 65, Original. State of Texas, plaintiff, v. State of New Mexico.
Report of Special on Obligation of New Mexico to Texas under the
Pecos River Compact received and ordered filed. Exceptions, if any,
together with supporting briefs to the Report may be filed by the par-
ties within 45 days. Replies, if any, with supporting briefs, to such ex-
ceptions may be filed within 30 days.
No. 78-756. Ohio, petitioner, v. Herschel Roberts. Motion of Ohio
Public Defenders Association for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae,
granted.
No. 78-857. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Yeshiva
University; and
No. 78-997. Yeshiva University Faculty Association petitioner, v.
Yeshiva University. Motion of Trustees of Boston University for leave
to file a brief, as amicus curiae, denied.

ment, granted.

Motion of The County of Alameda, State of California, for leave to
file a brief, as amicus curiae, denied.
No. 78-1327. The Boeing Company, petitioner, v. William R. Van
Gemert et al. Motions to designate counsel to argue on behalf of all
respondents or in the alternative to permit divided argument, denied.

Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion and petition.
No. 79-5004. Terry G. Parker, petitioner, v. Richard Roth. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Nebraska denied.
Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Blackmun
would grant certiorari.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1979
173
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice
Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
Nos. A-172 and A-332. Kirk B. Lenhard and George E. Franzen,
Clark County Deputy Public Defenders, individually and as next
friends acting on behalf of Jesse Walter Bishop, applicants, v.
Charles Wolff, Warden, Nevada State Prison System, et al. Appli-
cation for stay of execution of the sentence of death, presented to
Mr. Justice Brennan and by him referred to the Court, denied. Peti-
tion for rehearing of order of Court entered October 1, 1979, denied.
Mr. Justice Brennan would grant application for stay and petition
for rehearing. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration
or decision of this application and petition.
310-278-79-17



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1979
175
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79–80. Steven Lew Quattry, appellant, v. Florida. Appeal
from the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 79-359. Jack M. Lotze et al., appellants, v. Washington. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Washington. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice White, Mr.
Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Powell would note probable juris-
diction and set case for oral argument.
No. 79-5285. William Earl Hawk, appellant, v. Oregon. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Oregon. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-264. Howell C. Willis, applicant, v. United States. Appli-
cation for stay, addressed to Mr. Justice Marshall and referred to the
Court, denied.
No. D-180. In the Matter of Disbarment of Charles Samuel Car-
ter. It is ordered that Charles Samuel Carter of Washington, D.C.,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why
he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-181. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ralph Freedson. It is
ordered that Ralph Freedson, of Houston, Texas, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

176
MONDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1979
No. 67, Original. State of Idaho, ex rel. John V. Evans, Governor;
David H. Leroy, Attorney General; Joseph C. Greenley, Director,
Department of Fish and Game, plaintiffs, v. States of Oregon and
Washington. Motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate
in oral argument, as amicus curiae, granted and ten additional minutes
allotted for that purpose. Plaintiffs allotted an additional ten minutes
for oral argument.
No. 73, Original. State of California, plaintiff, v. State of Nevada.
Report of Special Master received and ordered filed. Exceptions, if
any, with supporting briefs to the Report may be filed by the parties
within 45 days. Reply briefs, if any, to such exceptions may be filed
within 30 days.
No. 78-253. Nolan Estes et al., petitioners, v. Metropolitan
Branches of Dallas NAACP et al.;
No. 78–282. Donald E. Curry et al., petitioners, v. Metropolitan
Branches of the Dallas NAACP et al.;

Branches of the Dallas NAACP et al. Motion of Dallas Alliance et al.
for leave to participate in oral argument, as amici curiae, denied. Mr.
Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.

vice, granted.

of Taxes of Vermont. Motion of Multistate Tax Commission et al.

State Tax Commission. Motion of appellant to dispense with printing
appendix granted.

ORAL ARGUMENT
Francis J. Lorson
No. 77–1844. City of Mobile, Alabama, et al., appellants, v. Wiley
L. Bolden et al.; and
No. 78-357. Robert R. Williams et al., appellants, v. Leila G. Brown
et al. Two hours allowed for oral reargument. Reargued by Mr.
Charles S. Rhyne for the appellants in No. 77–1844, by Mr. James U.
Blacksher for the appellees in No. 77-1844, by M. James P. Turner for
the United States, as amicus curiae, in support of the appellees in both
cases, by Mr. William H. Allen for the appellants in No. 78-357 and
by Mr. Eric Schnapper for the appellees in No. 78–357.
No. 78–253. Nolan Estes et al., petitioners, v. Metropolitan
Branches of Dallas NAACP et al.;
No. 78–282. Donald E. Curry et al., petitioners, v. Metropolitan
Branches of the Dallas NAACP et al.; and
No. 78–283. Ralph F. Brinegar et al., petitioners, v. Metropolitan
Branches of the Dallas NAACP et al. One and one half hours allowed
for oral argument. Argued by Mr. Warren Whitham for the peti-
tioners Estes et al., by Mr. Robert L. Blumenthal for the petitioners
Curry et al.; by Mr. James A. Donohoe for the petitioners Brinegar
et al., by Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace for the United States, as amicus
curiae, supporting respondents in each case, by Mr. E. Brice Cunning-
ham for respondents NAACP et al., and by Mr. Edward B. Cloutman,
III, for the respondents Tasby et al.
No. 78–5705. Otis Trammel, Jr., petitioner, v. United States. Ar-
gument commenced by Mr. J. Terry Wiggins for the petitioner.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

Guardian for Shawn D. Clark and Tricia D. Clark. Argued by Mrs.

for the appellee.

Roberts Harris, Secretary, Department of Health, Education and

mittee for Freedom of the Press et al.; and

Mr. Andrew L. Frey for the petitioner and by Mr. W. Gary Kohlman
for the respondent.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1979
203
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79–208. Isaac Kaplan, etc., appellant, v. Jerome Prince et al.
Appeal from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New
York, First Judicial Department. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part
in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 79-237. Alfred A. Greenberg, appellant, v. New Jersey. Appeal
from the Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Jus-
tice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-291. National Railroad Passenger Corporation, applicant,
v. Kansas ex rel. Robert T. Stephan, Attorney General, et al. Motion
for reconsideration of order entered by Mr. Justice White dated Oc-
tober 8, 1979, denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion.
No. A-322. A. Burton Hankins, applicant, v. United States et al.
Application for bail pending appeal, addressed to Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist and referred to the Court, denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of this application.
No. D–169. In the Matter of Disbarment of Donald S. Carnow.
Donald S. Carnow, of Chicago, Illinois, having requested to resign as
a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be
stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the
Bar of this Court. The rule to show cause heretofore issued on May 29,
1979, is hereby discharged. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the
consideration or decision of this order.
310-278-79-22

204
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1979
No. 78–1945. Universities Research Association, Inc., petitioner,
v. Stanley E. Coutu et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief
in this case expressing the views of the United States. Mr. Justice
Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. 78-6029. Anthony LaRocca, Jr., petitioner, v. United States.
Order of this Court dated October 1, 1979, appointing Michael A.
Litman, Esquire, of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, as counsel for peti-
tioner vacated. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this order.
No. 79-5010. Alphonse Bifulco, petitioner, v. United States. Mo-
tion of Phylis Skloot Bamberger for appointment of counsel granted,
and it is ordered that Steven Lloyd Barrett, Esquire, of New York,
New York, is appointed to serve as counsel for the petitioner in this
case. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this motion.
No. 79-5495. Roy Grant Miller, petitioner, v. United States. Ap-
plication for stay, addressed to Mr. Justice Rehnquist and referred
to the Court, denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this application.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 79–394. United States, petitioner, v. L. O. Ward, dba L. O.
Ward Oil and Gas Operations. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit granted. Mr.
Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this
petition.
No. 79-424. Board of Regents of the University of the State of
New York et al., petitioners, v. Mary Tomanio. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
granted. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or
decision of this petition.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 78–1913. Robert G. Mytnik, petitioner, v. Illinois. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District,
denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or
decision of this petition.
No. 78–6879. Herbert C. Fields, petitioner, v. Oklahoma. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Okla-
homa denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration
or decision of this petition.

RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Tuesday, November 13, 1979, until
Monday, November 26, 1979.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

310-278-79-26



(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1979
229
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and
Mr. Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78–6887. Raul Meza, Jr., appellant, v. Texas. Appeal from
the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied. Mr. Justice
Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 79–69. William J. Kelly, appellant, v. Pennsylvania. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari de-
nied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision
of this case.
No. 79-472. Darrell Darwin Smith, appellant, v. Oregon. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Oregon. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 79-502. Clifford S. Strike et al., appellants, v. Trans-West
Discount Corporation et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of Cali-
fornia, Fourth Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 79–5506. Curtis Brintley et al., appellants, v. Michigan. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Michigan. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-180. In the Matter of Charles Samuel Carter. Due to mis-
taken identity, the District of Columbia Bar having two attorneys on
its roster with identical names, the Rule to Show Cause is discharged.
310-278-79-27

230
TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1979
and the order entered October 29, 1979, vacated. Mr. Justice Marshall
took no part in the consideration or decision of this matter.
No. 78–1007. H. Earl Fullilove et al., petitioners, v. Juanita M.
Kreps, Secretary of Commerce of the United States et al. Motion of
petitioners General Building Contractors of New York, Inc., et al., for
divided argument granted. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 78-1369. Committee for Public Education and Religious Lib-
erty et al., appellants, v. Edward V. Regan, etc., et al. Motion of ap-
pellees for divided argument granted. Mr. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 78-1487. Ford Motor Credit Company et al., petitioners, v.
Dennis Milhollin et al. Motion of petitioners for divided argument
granted. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or
decision of this motion.
No. 78-1548. California Brewers Association, et al., petitioners, v.
Abram Bryant Motion of petitioners and respondent Unions for ad-
ditional time for oral argument denied. Alternative request for divided
argument granted. Motion of respondent Bryant for divided argu-
ment granted. Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Stevens took no
part in the consideration or decision of these motions.
No. 78–1780. Gentry Crowell, Secretary of State of Tennessee,
et al., appellants, v. Richard Mader et al. Appellants requested to file a
response to petition for rehearing within thirty days. Mr. Justice Mar-
shall took no part in the consideration or decision of this order.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED OR POSTPONED
No. 79–253. Ray Marshall, Secretary of Labor, et al., appellants,
v. Jerrico, Inc. Appeal from the United States Dist. Court for
the District of Columbia.
In this case probable jurisdiction
noted. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this matter.
No. 79–289. Prune Yard Shopping Center and Fred Sahadi, appel-
lants, v. Michael Robins et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Cali-
fornia. Further consideration of the question of jurisdiction post-
poned to the hearing of the case on the merits. Mr. Justice Marshall
took no part in the consideration or decision of this matter.

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1979
Sixth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this petition.
No. 79-5498. David R. Riggs, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 79-5500. John Edwin Waite, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in
the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 79-5502. William Eugene Young, petitioner, v. United States
Air Force Voluntary Induction Testing Center at Indianapolis, Indi-
ana. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Seventh Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 79–203. George Ochs, petitioner, v. United States. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sec-
ond Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Stewart would grant certiorari. Mr.
Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this
petition.
No. 79-5047. Yancy Leroy Britton, petitioner, v. Texas. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas de-
nied. Mr. Justice Stewart would grant certiorari. Mr. Justice Marshall
took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 79–347. City of Los Angeles, California, et al., petitioners, v.
Neil E. Goldschmidt, Secretary of Transportation, et al. Motion of
Airport Operators Council International for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit denied.
Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of
this petition.
No. 79-456. Arnall, Golden and Gregory, et al., petitioners, v.
Smith, Cohen, Ringel, Kohler & Martin et al. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
denied. Mr. Justice White would grant certiorari. Mr. Justice Mar-
shall took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 79-5114. Haney Warren, petitioner, v. Mississippi. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi denied. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Justice Brennan
and Mr. Justice Stewart join. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in
the consideration or decision of this petition.

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1979
239
No. 79–5247. Joseph Carl Shaw, petitioner, v. South Carolina.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South Carolina
denied. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Brennan. Mr. Justice
Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 79–5376. Howard Jones, petitioner, v. Georgia. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia denied. Dissent-
ing statement by Mr. Justice Brennan. Mr. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 79-5395. Ronald K. Spivey, petitioner, v. Walter Zant,
Warden. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Superior Court of Butts
County, Georgia, denied. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Bren-
nan. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this petition.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 78–1512. Beverly Ann Schwartz, by her next friend, Larry
Schwartz, petitioner, v. Gordon Gilster, Sheriff of Lincoln County,
Nebraska.
No. 78-1911. Robert L. Guyler Company, etc., petitioner, v. United
States;
No. 78-6657. Geneva H. Sayles, petitioner, v. United States Court
of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit et al.;
No. 78-6695. Virgil Delano Presnell, Jr., petitioner, v. Georgia;
No. 78-6733. Bill Barnett et ux., petitioners, v. Owen D. Cox,
Judge, United States District Court for the Southern District of
Texas, et al.;
No. 78-6881. Vatuk B. Prasad, petitioner, v. Richard Merges,
Director, Wassaic Developmental Center, et al.;
No. 79-160. Eugene W. Connelly, petitioner, v. Commercial Trad-
ing Co., Inc.;
No. 79–251. Earl L. Sappington, appellant, v. Paul R. Beckert,
etc., et al.;
No. 79-5131. Paul Lawrence Montgomery, petitioner, v. United
States.
No. 79–5148. LeVoy Meredith, petitioner, v. Ellis C. MacDougall,
Director, Arizona Department of Corrections, et al.;
No. 79-5185. Angel Manuel Garcia, Jr., petitioner, v. Indiana;
No. 79-5194. Sammie L. Page, petitioner, v. California; and
No. 79-5226. Roderick Marvin Greer, petitioner, v. United States.
Petitions for rehearing denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in
the consideration or decision of these petitions.

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1979
OPINION
257
No. 77-1645. Transamerica Mortgage Advisors, Inc. (TAMA),
et al., petitioners, v Harry Lewis. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed
in part and reversed in part, and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Concurring statement
by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White with
whom Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice
Stevens join.
Adjourned until Monday, November 26, 1979, at 10 o'clock.
☑



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1979
259
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice.
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said.
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79-458. Beatrice R. Donner, appellant, v. Paul B. Anton, et al.
Appeal from the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
The appeal is dismissed as jurisdictionally out of time.
No. 79-513. Royal D. Jennings, appellant, v. Robert F. Moore &
Larry Jennings et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Iowa. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied.
No. 79–549. William Beverly Smart, appellant, v. California. Ap-
peal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate Dis-
trict. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certi-
orari, certiorari denied.
No. 79-5374. Lawrence R. Topham, appellant, v. Knight Adjust-
ment Bureau. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Utah. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari
denied.
No. 79-610. John B. Holway et al., appellants, v. Jonathan Eng-
land et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77–1717. First Houston-Investment Corp. et al., petitioners, v..
John M. Wilson. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of
certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court
of appeals for further consideration in light of Transamerica Mort-
gage Advisors, Inc. v. Lewis, 444 U.S.— (1979).
310-278 0 - 80 - 29

260
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1979
No. 78-463. Chestnutt Management Corporation, petitioner, v.
Eleanor C. Miller. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Motion of Investment
Counsel Association of America, Inc. for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment va-
cated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consid-
eration in light of Transamerica Mortgage Advisors, Inc. v. Lewis,
444 U.S. (1979).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-371. Crystal Theater, Inc., et al., applicants, v. Henry
Wade, etc. et al. Application for stay, addressed to Mr. Justice Stew-
art and referred to the Court, denied. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr.
Justice Marshall would grant the application.
No. 78–1175. Hatzlachh Supply Co., Inc., petitioner, v. United
States. Motion of Solicitor General to permit Kent L. Jones, Esquire,
to present oral argument, pro hac vice, granted.
No. 78-1557. Nachman Corporation, petitoiner, v. Pension Benefit
Guaranty Corporation et al. Motion of General Motors Corporation
for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
No. 78-1577. Sears, Roebuck and Co., petitioner, v. County of Los
Angeles and City of Compton. Motion of Charles R. Ajalat et al. for
leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, granted. Motion of Charles R.
Ajalat et al. for leave to participate in oral argument, as amici curiae,
denied. Mr. Justice Stewart took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of these motions.
No. 78-1651. Seatrain Shipbuilding Corporation, et al. petitioners,
v. Shell Oil Company et al. Motion of Solicitor General to permit
Andrew J. Levander, Esquire, to present oral argument, pro hac vice,
on behalf of federal respondents, granted.
No. 78–1756. United States, petitioner, v. Helen Mitchell et al.
Motion of Chloe Whiskers et al. for leave to file a brief, as amici
curiae, denied.
No. 78–1821. United States, petitioner, v. Sylvia L. Mendenhall.
Motion of respondent for leave to proceed further herein in forma
pauperis granted.
No. 79-64. David Zbaraz, et al., petitioners, v. Arthur F. Quern,
etc., et al. Motion of Legal Defense Fund for Unborn Children for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, denied. Motion of Alan Ernest
for appointment as counsel for Children Unborn and Born Alive
denied.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1979
261
No. 79-67. William Walter, petitioner, v. United States; and
No. 79-148. Arthur Randall Sanders, Jr., et al., petitioners, v.
United States. Motion of petitioners for divided argument granted.
No. 79-97. California Retail Liquor Dealers Association, peti-
tioner, v. Midcal Aluminum, Inc., et al. Motion of State of California
for divided argument granted. Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 79-381. Paul J. Wengler, appellant, v. Druggists Mutual In-
surance Company et al. Motion of appellant to dispense with printing
appendix granted.
No. 79-408. City of Milwaukee et al., petitioners, v. Illinois and
Michigan; and
No. 79-571. Illinois, petitioner, v. City of Milwaukee et al.; and
No. 79-552. Mitsui & Co., Ltd., et al., petitioners, v. Industrial
Investment Development Corporation et al. The Solicitor General is
invited to file briefs in these cases expressing the views of the United
States.
No. 79-740. Keith L. Arthur, petitioner, v. United States. Appli-
cation for stay, addressed to Mr. Justice Rehnquist and referred to the
Court, denied.
No. 79-5567. Daniel Joseph Baker, petitioner, v. Georgia. Motion
of petitioner to expedite consideration of petition denied.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED OR POSTPONED
No. 79–509. Exxon Corporation, appellant v. Wisconsin Depart-
ment of Revenue. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. In
this case probable jurisdiction noted.
No. 79-565. Central Hudson Gas & Electric Corporation, appel-
lant, v. Public Service Commission of New York. Appeal from the
Court of Appeals of New York. In this case probable jurisdiction
noted. Case set for oral argument in tandem with No. 79-134, Consoli-
dated Edison Company of New York, Inc. v. Public Service Commis-
sion of New York.
No. 79-4. Jasper F. Williams and Eugene F. Diamond, appellants,
v. David Zbaraz et al.;
No. 79-5. Arthur F. Quern, Director, Illinois Department of Public
Aid et al., appellants, v. David Zbaraz, et al.; and
No. 79-491. United States, appellant, v. David Zbaraz et al. Ap-
peals from the United States District Court for the Northern District
of Illinois. Motion of Legal Defense Fund for Unborn Children for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, denied. Motion of Alan Ernest

262
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1979-
for appointment as counsel for Children Unborn and Born Alive, de-
nied. Motion of Cora McRae et al. for leave to file a brief, as amici
curiae, denied. Further consideration of the question of jurisdiction is
postponed to the hearing of the cases on the merits. Cases consolidated
and a total of one and one half hours allotted for oral argument.

writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit granted.

tioners, v. Glover Construction Company. Motion of Arctic Slope Re-

Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit granted.

Hollis Clinton
James G. Grennan
Oklahoma City,
Okla.
Lewis, Jr.
George G. Olsen
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 67, Original. State of Idaho, ex rel. John V. Evans, Governor;
David H. Leroy, Attorney General; Joseph C. Greenley, Director, De-
partment of Fish and Game, plaintiffs, v. States of Oregon and Wash-
ington. One hour and twenty minutes allowed for oral argument.
Argued by Mr. David H. Leroy for the plaintiffs, by Mr. James A.
Redden for the respondent, State of Oregon, by Mr. Slade Gorton for
the respondent, State of Washington, and by Mr. Louis F. Claiborne
for the United States, as amicus curiae, by special leave of Court.
No. 77-6219. Thomas Baldasar, petitioner, v. Illinois. Argued by
Mr. Michael Mulder for the petitioner and by Mr. Michael B. Wein-
stein for the respondent.
No. 78–756. Ohio, petitioner, v. Herschel Roberts. Argued by Mr.
John E. Shoop for the petitioner and by Mr. Marvin R. Plasco for
the respondent. Memorandum from respondent to come.
No. 78-1453. United States et al., petitioners, v. Harvey F. Euge.
Argued by Mr. Stuart A. Smith for the petitioner and by Mr. James

OPINIONS
No. 78-425. P. C. Pfeiffer Company, Inc., et al., petitioners, v.
Divers on Ford et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Powell.
No. 78–740. Cecil D. Andrus, Secretary of the Interior, et al., ap-
pellants, v. L. Douglas Allard et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the District of Colorado. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the United States District Court for the District of
Colorado for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Mr. Chief Justice Burger
concurs in the judgment.
No. 78-959. Vincent R. Perrin, Jr., petitioner, v. United States.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger. Mr. Justice White took no part in the decision of this case.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1979
295
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said;
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79-324. Estate of W. T. Grant Company (Bankrupt), appel-
lant, v. Gerald A. Lewis, Comptroller of the State of Florida, et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 79–623. Alvin H. Eisenberg, Co-Personal Representative of
the Estate of Betty R. Eisenberg, appellant v. Jack M. Eisenberg. Ap-
peal from the Court of Appeals of Wisconsin. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 79–597. Ernest E. Webber et al., appellants, v. City of Sacra-
mento et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79–173. Kentucky, petitioner, v. Norwood Wells. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Kentucky. Motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals of Kentucky for further consideration in light
of Kentucky v. Whorton, 441 U.S. 786 (1979).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-447. Burlington Northern Inc., applicant, v. United States
et al. Application for stay, presented to the Chief Justice and by him
referred to the Court, denied.
No. D-182. In the Matter of Disbarment of Leonard Saul Blondes.
It is ordered that Leonard Saul Blondes, of Silver Spring, Maryland,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule

296
MONDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1979
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why
he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

United States, petitioner, v. James T. Cogdell. Motion of respondents
for leave to file a supplemental brief, after argument, granted.
No. 78–1177. White Mountain Apache Tribe et al., petitioners, v.
Robert M. Bracker et al. Motion of the Solicitor General for leave to
participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, granted and ten addi-

denied.

denied.

OPINIONS
McCree, Jr.
No. 78-5981. Francis Rick Ferri, petitioner, e. Daniel Ackerman.
On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Western
District. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court
of Pennsylvania, Western District, for further proceedings not incon-
sistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 78-738. Kaiser Aetna et al., petitioners, v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice
Marshall join.
No. 77–1819. Norman Vaughn, Freddie Broussard and Larry J.
Broussard, petitioners, v. Vermilion Corporation. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit. Judg-
ment affirmed with respect to the second question presented by the
petition for a writ of certiorari and vacated with respect to the first
question and case remanded to the Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third
Circuit, for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion in
No. 78-738, ante. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr.
Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 78-1455. United States, petitioner, v. Edgar H. Gillock.
Argued by Mr. Solicitor General Wade H. McCree, Jr. for the peti-
tioner and by Mr. James V. Doramus for the respondent.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1979
313
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr.
Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79–161. Philip Abbott Masquelette, appellant, v. Texas. Ap-
peal from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 79-302. Warren Rankins, etc., et al., appellants, v. Com-
mission on Professional Competence of the Ducor Union School Dis-
trict et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Stevens would note
probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 79-617. Muriel S. Smith, appellant, v. Rose Penta, etc., et
al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Jersey. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 79-628. California Association of Utility Shareholders, ap-
pellant, v Public Utilities Commission of the State of California et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 79–5507. J. K. S., appellant, v. Colorado. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Colorado. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 79–5545. Norwood L. White, appellant, v. New Jersey. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of New Jersey. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 79–5323. David Hernandez Apodaca, appellant, v. Texas. Ap-
peal from the County Court at Law Number Two, El Paso County,
Texas. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal ques-
tion. Mr. Justice Stewart would dismiss the appeal for want of a prop-
erly presented federal question. Mr. Justice Marshall would note
☐ probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument.
310-278-79-36

314
MONDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1979
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77–1543. Kenneth E. Powell, petitioner, v. Cargill, Inc., et al.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further consideration in light of P. C. Pfeiffer Co. v. Ford, 444 U.S.—
(1979). Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
No. 78–1933. Steven H. Montgomery, etc., petitioner, v. Century
Laminating, Ltd. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Motion of respondent to dismiss granted
and writ of certiorari dismissed as improvidently granted.
No. 78–6153. Francis Rick Ferri, petitioner, v. Dominick Rossetti.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Pennsyl-
vania, Western District. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Pennsyl-
vania, Western District, for further consideration in light of Ferri v.
Ackerman, 444 U.S. (1979).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-430. Norbert A. Schueller, petitioner, v. Lyon Moving &
Storage Co. Application for an extension of time in which to file a peti-
tion for writ of certiorari, addressed to Mr. Justice Marshall and re-
ferred to the Court, denied.
No. A-458. Russell E. Lerman, applicant, v. Inhabitants of City of
Portland. Application for stay, addressed to Mr. Justice Marshall and
referred to the Court, denied.
No. 78–1418. William E. Bloomer, Jr., petitioner, v. Liberty Mu-
tual Insurance Company, etc. Motion of Hudson Waterways Corpora-
tion et al. for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, denied.
No. 78–1693. United States, petitioner, v. Glen M. Clarke et al.
Motion of the Solicitor General for divided argument granted.
No. 78–1793. Winfield L. Roberts, petitioner, v. United States.
Motion of the American Civil Liberties Union et al. for leave to file
a brief, as amici curiae, granted.
No. 78-6885. Flynn Noye Hicks, petitioner, v. Oklahoma. Motion
for appointment of counsel granted and it is ordered that David M.
Ebel, Esquire, of Denver, Colorado, is appointed to serve as counsel
for petitioner in this case.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1979
315
No. 79–97. California Retail Liquor Dealers Association, petitioner,
v. Midcal Aluminum, Inc., et al. Respondent's motion for reconsidera-
tion of order of November 26, 1979, granting divided argument denied.
Further consideration of respondent's suggestion of mootness deferred
to the hearing of the case on the merits. Mr. Justice Brennan took no
part in the consideration or decision of these matters.
No. 79–539. Maine, petitioner, v. Albert C. Dana, Jr. and Allen J.
Sockabasin. Solicitor General invited to file a brief in this case ex-
pressing the views of the United States.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 79–488. General Telephone Company of the Northwest, Inc.,
et al., petitioners, v. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 79–639. United States, petitioner, v. Sioux Nation of Indians,
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Claims granted.
No. 79–244. United States, petitioner, v. John M. Salvucci, Jr. and
Joseph G. Zackular. Motions of respondents for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the First Circuit granted. Case set for oral argu-
ment in tandem with No. 79-5146, Rawlings v. Kentucky.
No. 79–616. Mohasco Corporation, petitioner, v. Ralph H. Silver.
Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit granted limited to Question 1 presented by the
petition.
No. 79-5146. David Rawlings, petitioner, v. Kentucky. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kentucky granted. Case
set for oral argument in tandem with No. 79-244, United States v.
Salvucci.
No. 79–5175. Randall Dale Adams, petitioner, v. Texas. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas granted lim-
ted to the questions presented by the Court: (1) Is the doctrine of
Witherspoon v. Illinois, 391 U.S. 510, applicable to the bifurcated
procedure employed by Texas in capital cases? (2) If so, did the ex-
clusion from jury service in the present case of prospective jurors
bursuant to Texas Penal Code § 12.31 (b) violate the doctrine of
Witherspoon v. Illinois, supra?

OPINION
No. 78–1183. Carbon Fuel Company, petitioner, v. United Mine
Workers of America et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Brennan.
Adjourned until Monday, January 7, 1980, at 10 o'clock.

(Journal)
THURSDAY, DECEMBER 13, 1979
333
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 79-856. Barry Goldwater et al., petitioners, 7. James Earl
Carter, President of the United States, et al. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment
vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court for
the District of Columbia with directions to dismiss the complaint. Mr.
Justice Marshall concurs in the result. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell
concurring in the judgment. Concuring opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Stewart
and Mr. Justice Stevens join. Statement by Mr. Justice Blackmun
dissenting in part with whom Mr. Justice White joins. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan.
Х
310-278-79
..༦



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JANUARY 7, 1980
335
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 79-168 Strycker's Bay Neighborhood Council, Inc., petitioner,
v. Roland N. Karlen et al.;
No. 79–181. City of New York, petitioner, v. Roland N. Karlen
et al.; and
No. 79–184. Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, peti-
tioner, v. Roland N. Karlen et al. On petitions for writs of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Peti-
tions for writs of certiorari granted, judgment reversed and cases
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissent-
ing opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79–270. Charles Gene Heads, appellant, v. Louisiana. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Louisiana for
further consideration in light of Sandstrom v. Montana, 442 U.S.
(1979).
No. 79-409. Robert J. Cahill, appellant, v. Governmental Ethics
Commission. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Kansas. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari
denied.
No. 79–665. James L. Pickering, appellant, v. Commissioner of
Internal Revenue. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals

MONDAY, JANUARY 7, 1980
for the Second Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-

No. 79-699. William P. Heyne, appellant, v. Margaret L. Heyne
et. al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Summit County.

certiorari denied.
No. 79-413. Adelyn J. Crawford, appellant, v. New York. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is dismissed for

No. 79–704. Sherwood Slate, appellant, v. Joseph N. Noll. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Western District of
Wisconsin. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Marshall would not prob-
able jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 79-5411. Leland Sammons, appellant, v. Ohio. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Ohio. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
