ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 78–6386. William James Rummel, petitioner, v. W. J. Estelle,
Jr., Director, Texas Department of Corrections. Argued by Mr. Scott
J. Atlas for the petitioner and by Mr. Douglas M. Becker for the
respondent.
No. 78-1261. Norman A. Carlson, Director, Federal Bureau of
Prisons, et al., petitioners, v. Marie Green, Administratrix of the
Estate of Joseph Jones, Jr. Argued by Mr. Kenneth S. Geller for the
petitioners and by Mr. Michael E. Deutsch for the respondent.
No. 78-1557. Nachman Corporation, petitioner, v. Pension Bene-
fit Guaranty Corporation et al. Argued by Mr. Robert W. Gettleman
for the petitioner, by Mr. Henry Rose for the respondent Pension
Benefit Guaranty Corp., and by Mr. M. Jay Whitman for the re-
spondent UAW.
No. 78-1595. George Calvin Lewis, Jr., petitioner v. United States.
Argued by Mr. Andrew W. Wood for the petitioner and by Mr. An-
drew J. Levander for the respondent, pro hac vice, by special leave
of Court.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

OPINION
No. 78-1501. James Jefferson McLain et al., petitioners, v. Real
Estate Board of New Orleans, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
ORAL ARGUMENT

son, Warden. Argued by Mr. Carl Ziemba for the petitioner and by
Mr. Robert A. Derengoski for the respondent.

Missouri, et al. Argued by Mr. Irving Achtenberg for the petitioner
and by Mr. Richard G. Carlisle for the respondents.

poration. Argued by Mr. Don Manners for the petitioner and by
Mr. Jay M. Galt for the respondent.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

310-278-79-44



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JANUARY 14, 1980
377
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 79-5180. Roger Dale Thompson, petitioner, v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Sixth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment va-
cated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for reconsidera-
tion in light of the government's present position. Opinion per curiam.
The Chief Justice and Mr. Justice White dissent. Dissenting state-
ment by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist
joins.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78–1422. Retirement Fund Trust of the Plumbing, Heating
and Piping Industry of Southern California, appellant, v. Edith J.
Johns. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Fourth Ap-
pellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-1881. Carpenters Pension Trust Fund for Northern Cali-
fornia appellant, v. Christine Campa et al. Appeal from the Court of
Appeal of California, First Appellate District. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79-136. Sidney A. Diamond, Commissioner of Patents and
Trademarks, petitioner, v. Malcolm E. Bergy et al. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals.
Judgment as to case No. 76-712, In the Matter of Application of
Malcolm E. Bergy, John H. Coats, and Vedpal S. Malik, vacated and
that case remanded to the United States Court of Customs and Patent
Appeals with directions to dismiss the appeal as moot.
310-278-79-45

378
MONDAY, JANUARY 14, 1980
No. 79-759. Perini North River Associates et al., petitioners, v.
Ronald Fusco and Bernard Sullivan. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Petition
for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for fur-
ther consideration in light of P. C. Pfeiffer Co. v. Ford, 444 U.S.
(1979). Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice
Blackmun dissent.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-538. Albert Gusikoff et al., applicants, v. United States.
Application for stay pending appeal to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, addressed to Mr. Justice Marshall and
referred to the Court, denied.
No. A-592. Burlington Northern, Inc., applicant, v. United States
et al. Application for stay of an order of the Interstate Commerce
Commission pending appeal to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit, presented to Mr. Justice Stewart and by him
referred to the Court, denied.
No. D-170. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert Baer Cohen.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-172. In the Matter of Disbarment of Maurice Albert Bendes.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-174. In the Matter of Disbarment of Daniel J. Spooner.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-183. In the Matter of Disbarment of Harry Davis Barnes.
It is ordered that Harry Davis Barnes, of Elkton, Maryland, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty day, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 9, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Louisiana et al. Exceptions to the Report of the Special Master set
for oral argument in due course. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in
the consideration or decision of this order.
No. 78-6029. Anthony LaRocca, Jr., petitioner, v. United States.
Motion for appointment of counsel granted and it is ordered that
Gerald Goldman, Esquire, of Washington, D.C. is appointed to serve
as counsel for petitioner in this case.
No. 79-4. Jasper F. Williams and Eugene F. Diamond, appellants,
v. David Zbaraz et al.;
No. 79-5. Jeffrey C. Miller, Acting Director, Illinois Department
of Public Aid, et al., appellants, v. David Zbaraz et al.; and

MONDAY, JANUARY 14, 1980
379
No. 79-491. United States, appellant, v. David Zbaraz et al. Motion
of Alan Ernest to be appointed counsel for Children Unborn and Born
Alive, denied. Motion of Legal Defense Fund for Unborn Children for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, denied.
No. 79-48. Cecil D. Andrus, Secretary of the Interior, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Glover Construction Company. Motion of petitioner to dis-
pense with printing the appendix granted.
No. 79–134. Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc.,
appellant, v. Public Service Commission of New York. Motion of New
England Legal Foundation for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae,
granted. Motion of Long Island Lighting Company for leave to file a
brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Motion of New York State Consumer
Protection Board et al. for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, granted.
No. 79–136. Sidney A. Diamond, Commissioner of Patents and
Trademarks, petitioner, v. Malcolm E. Bergy, et al. Motion of Cornell
D. Cornish for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
No. 79–192. New York Gaslight Club, Inc., et al., petitioners, v.
Cidni Carey. Motion of New York State Division of Human Rights et
al. for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, granted.
No. 79–5863. James Godwin, petitioner, v. United States. Motion
of petitioner to seal petition denied.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 79–492. Robert Michael Fungaroli, appellant, v. Judith Diane
Fungaroli. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of North Carolina. Mo-
tion of appellee for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. In this
case probable jurisdiction noted.

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 78-1604. Central Machinery Company, appellant, v. Arizona
State Tax Commission. Argued by Mr. Rodney B. Lewis for the
appellant, by Mr. Louis F. Claiborne for the United States, as amicus
curiae, by special leave of Court, and by Mr. Ian A. Macpherson for
the appellee.
No. 78–1177. White Mountain Apache Tribe et al., petitioners, v.
Robert M. Bracker et al. One hour and twenty minutes allowed for
oral argument. Argued by Mr. Neil Vincent Wake and Mr. Michael J.
Brown for the petitioners, by Mrs. Elinor H. Stillman for the United
States, as amicus curiae, by special leave of the Court, and by Mr. Ian
A. Macpherson for the respondents.
No. 79-105. Curtiss-Wright Corporation, petitioner, v. General
Electric Company. Argued by Mr. Ralph N. Del Deo for the petitioner
and by Mr. Isaac N. Groner for the respondent.
No. 78-1793. Winfield L. Roberts, petitioner, v. United States.
Argument commenced by Mr. Allan M. Palmer for the petitioner.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

OPINIONS
No. 78-1268. George Martinez et al., appellants, v. California
et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Fourth Ap-
pellate District. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 78-1143. Cyrus Vance, Secretary of State of the United
States, appellant, v. Laurence J. Terrazas. Appeal from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
White. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall concurring in part and
dissenting in part. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens concurring in part
and dissenting in part. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan
with whom Mr. Justice Stewart joins as to Part II. Dissenting state-
ment by Mr. Justice Stewart.

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 78–1793. Winfield L. Roberts, petitioner, v. United States.

and concluded by Mr. Allan M. Palmer for the petitioner.

Los Angeles and City of Compton. Argued by Mr. Andrew S. Garb
for the petitioner, by Mr. Ernest J. Brown for the United States, as
amicus curiae, by special leave of Court, and by Mr. James Dexter
Clark for the respondents.

etc., appellant, v. BT Investment Managers, Inc., et al. Argued by Mr.
Ervin N. Griswold for the appellant and by Mr. John L. Warden for
the appellees.
No. 78-1815. Cecil D. Andrus, Secretary of Interior, petitioner. v.
Shell Oil Company et al. Argued by Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace for the
petitioner and by Mr. Fowler Hamilton for the respondents.
No. 78–1693. United States, petitioner, v. Glen M. Clarke et al.
Argument commenced by Mr. Harlon L. Dalton for the petitioner.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

Х
310-278-79-47



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JANUARY 21, 1980
395
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"It is my sad duty to announce that our friend and colleague Wil-
liam O. Douglas died Saturday, January 19, 1980.
"For five years, since he suffered a severe stroke on New Year's Eve
of 1974, Justice Douglas' courage and determination exemplified a
quality that characterized his entire life. All of us who knew him
well, and thousands who had no personal acquaintance with him,
shared an admiration for his brave struggle to regain health and
strength.
"His retirement in November 1975 came after the longest tenure in
the history of this Court. When he achieved this record in October
1973, we took note from this Bench of his extraordinary career, his
devotion to freedom, his concern for our environment, his involve-
ment in countless causes relating to the improvement of the human
condition.
"Justice Douglas' public and judicial career spanned more than four
decades of massive social, political and economic changes in our coun-
try, and upheavals in the established order all over the world. Those
changes had large impact on the kinds of issues coming before this
Court. His mark on this crucial period in our history is a very sig-
nificant one. His judicial opinions appear in nearly one fourth of the
more than 440 volumes of the United States Reports.
"I last saw Justice Douglas within the hour before he returned to
the hospital and at that time I could see no lessening of that firm,
even fierce, determination he showed in every contest in his life. He
fought to the very end as he had always done.
"We mourn his passing but we will not forget the comradeship and
friendship that overshadowed the inescapable differences on the vex-
ing issues that historically confront this Court.
"In due course a memorial service of the Bar will be held in this
Chamber to more fully pay our respects, and those of the Supreme
Court Bar, to Mr. Justice Douglas."
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
310-278 0-80- -48

396
MONDAY, JANUARY 21, 1980
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 79-5386. Charles Tague, petitioner, v. Louisiana. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana. Motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court
of Louisiana for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion per curiam. The Chief Justice would set case
for oral argument. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79-606. Lumber, Production and Industrial Workers Local
2362, appellant, v. Robert A. Wondzell et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Alaska. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question. Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist would
note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 79-776. Erich Koker et ux., appellants, v. Noel B. Sage et al.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari.
certiorari denied.
No. 79-834. Automobile Drivers & Demonstrators Union Local
No. 882, et al., appellants, v. Department of Retirement Systems of
Washington. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Washington. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari
denied.
No. 79–5694. Vadie Colleen Parish, appellant, v. Charles Robert
Parish. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Alabama. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 79–787. Edward F. Kavanagh et al., appellants, v. London
Grove Township et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsyl-
vania, Eastern District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 79–820. Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, ap-
pellant, v. Minnesota, etc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Minne-
sota. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal ques-
tion. The Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 79-5465. Vasil M. Markoff, appellant, v. American Heritage
Life Insurance et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Nevada. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a properly presented federal question.

OPINIONS
No. 67, Original. State of Idaho, ex rel. John V. Evans, Governor;
David H. Leroy, Attorney General; Joseph C. Greenley, Director,
Department of Fish and Game, plaintiff, v. States of Oregon and
Washington. On exceptions to Report of Special Master. Exceptions
of Idaho recommending that Idaho's complaint be dismissed sustained
and case remanded to the Special Master for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Jus-
tice Marshall.
No. 78–990. United States, petitioner, v. Clifford Bailey et al.;
United States, petitioner v. James T. Cogdell. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Cir-
cuit. Judgments reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins. Mr.
Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 27, Original. State of Ohio, plaintiff, v. Commonwealth of
Kentucky. On exceptions to Report of Special Master. Exceptions of
Kentucky to Report of Special Master overruled, Report hereby

MONDAY, JANUARY 21, 1980
409
adopted, and case remanded to Special Master so that with the coop-
eration of the parties he may prepare and submit to the Court an
appropriate form of decree. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr. Justice White
and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 78-952. Randal Rush et al., appellants, v. Jeffrey D. Savchuk.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Minnesota. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Minnesota for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan
in this case and No. 78-1078, post. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
No. 78–1078. World-Wide Volkswagen Corporation et al., peti-
tioners, v. Charles S. Woodson, District Judge of Creek County, Okla-
homa, et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Oklahoma.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of
Oklahoma for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan in this case and No. 78-952, ante. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Blackmun
joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
No. 78-1006. Harold R. Brown, Secretary of Defense, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Albert Edward Glines. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed.
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Powell announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Brennan in this case and No. 78-599, post. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
= Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Mr. Justice Marshall
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 78–599. Secretary of the Navy et al., petitioners, v. Frank L.
Huff et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam an-
nounced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Brennan in this case and No. 78-1006, ante. Dissenting
statement by Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Stevens. Mr. Justice
Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 78–253. Nolan Estes et al., petitioners, v. Metropolitan
Branches of Dallas NAACP et al.;

410
MONDAY, JANUARY 21, 1980
No. 78–282. Donald E. Curry et al., petitioners, v. Metropolitan
Branches of the Dallas NAACP et al.; and
No. 78–283. Ralph F. Brinegar et al., petitioners, v. Metropolitan
Branches of the Dallas NAACP et al. On writs of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Writs of cer-
tiorari dismissed as improvidently granted. Opinion per curiam an-.
nounced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Powell with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist join.
No. 78–1175. Hatzlachh Supply Co., Inc., petitioner, v. United
States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Claims.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States Court of
Claims for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
Adjourned until Tuesday, February 19, 1980, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1980
411
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
lice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 78-1871. Frank W. Snepp, III, petitioner, v. United States;
and
No. 79–265. United States, petitioner, v. Frank W. Snepp, III.
On petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fourth Circuit. Petitions for writs of certiorari granted,
judgment reversed, insofar as it refused to impose a constructive trust
on Snepp's profits, and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for
reinstatement of the full judgment of the United States District Court
for the Eastern District of Virginia. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and
Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 78-1780. Gentry Crowell, Secretary of State of Tennessee, et
al., appellants, v. Richard Mader et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee. Petition for re-
hearing granted, order entered October 1, 1979, vacated, and judgment
vacated, without prejudice, and case remanded to the United States
District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee for such further
proceedings in the District Court as may be appropriate. Opinion per
curiam.

whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied.

appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.

CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78–1005. Harold R. Brown, Secretary of Defense, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Wayne M. Allen et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of Secretary of
the Navy v. Huff, 144 U.S. - (1980).
No. 79–517. Eschmann Bros. & Walsh, Ltd., petitioner, v. V. Muel-
ler & Co. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals
of Colorado. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment va-
cated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals of Colorado for
further consideration in light of World-Wide Volkswagen Corp. v.
Woodson, 444 U.S.
-
(1980).
No. 79-5215. Pamela Otis Subler, petitioner, (In the Matter of
Angela Marie Otis, et al.). On writ of certiorari to the Court of Ap-
peals of Ohio, Van Wert County. Upon consideration of motion of
petitioner for summary reversal, it is ordered that judgment of Court
of Appeals of Ohio, Van Wert County, is vacated and case remanded
to that court for further consideration in light of State ex rel. Heller
v. Miller, 61 Ohio St. 2d 6 (1980).
No. 79–5499. Joe E. Skipper, petitioner v. Bennett H. Brummer,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. Upon consideration of the motion of the State of
Florida for reconsideration of the order of this Court entered on
January 7, 1980, it is ordered that the judgment is vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light
of subsequent proceedings referred to in respondent's motion for re-
consideration and supplement thereto.

No. 84, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Alaska. It is ordered that J. Keith Mann, Esquire, of Stanford, Cali-
fornia, is appointed Special Master in this case with authority to fix
the time and conditions for the filing of additional pleadings and to
direct subsequent proceedings, and with authority to summon wit-
nesses, issue subpoenas, and take such evidence as may be introduced.
and such as he may deem necessary to call for. The Master is directed
to submit such reports as he may deem appropriate. The Master shall
be allowed his actual expenses. The allowances to him, the compensa-
tion paid to his technical, stenographic and clerical assistants, the cost
of printing his report, and all other proper expenses shall be charged
against and be borne by the parties in such proportion as the Court

416
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1980
may hereafter direct. It is further ordered that if the position of
Special Master in this case becomes vacant during a recess of the
Court, the Chief Justice shall have authority to make a new designa- 1
tion which shall have the same effect as if originally made by the
Court.

have sixty days to answer.

No. 79-870. United States Railroad Retirement Board, appellant,

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1980
No. 79–983. United States, appellant, v. Hubert L. Will et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
trict of Illinois. Further consideration of the question of jurisdiction
is postponed to the hearing of the case on the merits. In addition to
the questions presented by the statement as to jurisdiction, the parties
are directed to address the effect of 28 U.S.C. 455 on the jurisdiction
of the District Court and on the jurisdiction of this Court.
No. 79–1268. Patricia R. Harris, Secretary of Health, Education,
and Welfare, appellant, v. Cora McRae et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York.
Application for stay of judgment of the United States District Court
for the Eastern District of New York, presented to Mr. Justice Mar-
shall and by him referred to the Court, is denied. The Chief Justice,
Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist would grant applica-
tion. Treating the application as a statement as to jurisdiction, prob-
able jurisdiction noted. Appellees' request to expedite the briefing
schedule granted. Opening briefs on the merits shall be filed on or
before March 18, 1980. Replies thereto shall be filed on or before April
10, 1980. Case set for oral argument in tandem with No. 79-4, Williams
v. Zbaraz; No. 79-5, Miller v. Zbaraz; and No. 79-491, United States
v. Zbaraz.

OPINIONS
No. 78-1323. Norfolk and Western Railway Company, petitioner,
v. Kandythe J. Liepelt, Administratix, etc. On writ of certiorari to
the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, for
further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins.
No. 78–1327. The Boeing Company, petitioner, v. William R. Van
Gemert et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 78–1821. United States, petitioner, v. Sylvia L. Mendenhall.
Argued by Mr. Andrew L. Frey for the petitioner and by Mr. F. Ran-
dall Karfonta for the respondent.
No. 79–192. New York Gaslight Club, Inc., et al., petitioners, v.
Cidni Carey. Argued by Mr. Albert N. Proujansky for the petitioners,
by Mr. James I. Meyerson for the respondent, and by Mrs. Harriet S.
Shapiro for the United States et al., as amici curiae, by special leave
of Court.
No. 79–243. Richmond Newspapers, Inc., et al., appellants v. Vir-
ginia et al. Argued by Mr. Laurence H. Tribe for the appellants and
by Mr. J. Marshall Coleman for the appellees.

appellees.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

OPINIONS
No. 78–1453. United States et al., petitioners, v. Harvey F. Euge.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens join. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
No. 78-857. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Yes-
hiva University; and
No. 78–997. Yeshiva University Faculty Association, petitioner,
v. Yeshiva University. On writs of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan
with whom Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice
Blackmun join.
No. 78-1335. Village of Schaumburg, petitioner, v. Citizens for a
Better Environment et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
No. 78–1369. Committee for Public Education and Religious Lib-
erty et al., appellants, v. Edward V. Regan, etc., et al. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the Southern District of New
York. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and
Mr. Justice Marshall join. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 78-1548. California Brewers Association et al., petitioners,
v. Abram Bryant et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-

Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr.
Justice Brennan joins. Mr. Justice White took no part in the consid-

in the decision of these cases.

No. 79–959. Iowa Electric Light and Power Company, petitioner, v.
Atlas Corporation. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice White
and Mr. Justice Powell would grant certiorari in order to address
the conflict among state and federal courts noted in Mr. Justice
White's dissent from the denial of certiorari in Lakeside Bridge &
Steel Co. v. Mountain State Construction Co., No. 79-376. Mr. Jus-
tice Blackmun would grant certiorari and set case for oral argument.

Tarbutton et al. Petitions for rehearing denied.

for rehearing denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this petition.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, March 3, 1980, until
Monday, March 17, 1980.

OPINIONS
No. 78–1513. United States, appellant, v. Patricia Ilene Clark,
Guardian for Shawn D. Clark and Tricia D. Clark. Appeal from the
United States Court of Claims. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell concurring in the
judgment with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Justice Stewart
joins.
No. 78–1870. Whirlpool Corporation, petitioner v. Ray Marshall,
Secretary of Labor. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Stewart.
No. 78–1874. Massachusetts petitioner v. Joseph Meehan. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts. Writ of
certiorari dismissed as improvidently granted. Opinion per curiam
announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 79-67. William Walter, petitioner v. United States; and
No. 79–148. Arthur Randall Sanders, Jr., et al., petitioners v.
United States. Argued by Mr. Glenn Zell for the petitioners in No.
79-148, by Mr. Michael Mayock for the petitioner in No. 79-67, and
by Mr. Elliott Schulder for the respondent in both cases.
No. 79-1 American Export Lines, Inc., petitioner, v. Gilberto Alvez
et al. Argued by Mr. Stephen K. Carr for the petitioner and by Mr.
Paul C. Matthews for the respondents.

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1980

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

Marshall and Mr. Justice Powell join.

Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart concurring in the judgment.

by Mr. Steven Lloyd Barrett for the petitioner and by Mr. Harlon L.

the respondents in both cases.
Adjourned until Monday, March 3, 1980 at 10 o'clock.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 3, 1980
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
487
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackman, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79–928. Bridgeport Hydraulic Co. et al., appellants, v. Divi-
sion of Public Utility Control, etc.; and
No. 79–936. New Haven Water Company et al., appellants, v.
Division of Public Utility Control, etc. Appeals from the Superior
Court of Connecticut for Judicial District of Hartford-New Britain.
The appeals are dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 79–1073. Mutual of Omaha Insurance Company, appellant,
v. Michael Egan. Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The
appeal dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers where-
on the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari
denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-67. Trustees of Boston University, petitioner, v. National
Labor Relations Board et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. The petition for
a writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit for further
consideration in light of National Labor Relations Board v. Yeshiva
University, 444 U.S. —— – (1980).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 83, Original. State of Maryland et al., plaintiffs, v. State of
Louisiana. Motion for appointment of Special Master granted. Motion
of Columbia Gas Transmission Corporation et al. for leave to file an
answer to motion for appointment of Special Master granted.
It is ordered that John F. Davis, Esquire, of Washington, D.C., is
appointed Special Master in this case with authority to fix the time
and conditions for the filing of additional pleadings and to direct sub-
sequent proceedings, and with authority to summon witnesses, issue
310-278 0-80-57

488
MONDAY, MARCH 3, 1980
subpoenas, and take such evidence as may be introduced and such as
he may deem necessary to call for. The Special Master is directed to
submit such reports as he may deem appropriate.
The compensation of the Special Master, the allowances to him, the
compensation paid to his technical, stenographic and clerical assist-
ants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper expenses
shall be charged against and be borne by the parties in such propor-
tion as the Court may hereafter direct.
It is further ordered that if the position of Special Master in this
case becomes vacant during a recess of the Court, the Chief Justice
shall have authority to make a new designation which shall have the
same effect as if originally made by the Court herein.
Motion of Columbia Gas Transmission Corporation et al. for leave
to intervene and motion of New Jersey for leave to intervene are
referred to the Special Master. Motion of plaintiffs for judgment on
the pleadings and motion of Columbia Gas Transmission Corporation
et al. for leave to file motion for judgment on pleadings are referred
to the Special Master. Motion of Associated Gas Distributors for leave.
to file a brief, as amicus curiae, referred to the Special Master.
No. 84 Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Alaska. Motion for leave to file counterclaim referred to the Special
Master.
No. 79–289. Prune Yard Shopping Center and Fred Sahadi, ap-
pellants, v. Michael Robins et al. Motion of Solicitor General for di-
vided argument granted. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 79-703. Bernard Carey, etc.. appellant, v. Roy Brown et al.
Motion of New England Legal Foundation for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, granted. Motion of Pacific Legal Foundation et al. for
leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, granted.
No. 79-1082. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Inter-
national Longshoremen's Association, AFL-CIO, et al. Motion of
the Solicitor General for additional time for oral argument granted
and fifteen additional minutes are allotted for that purpose. Respond-
ents also allotted fifteen additional minutes for oral argument.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 79-824. Federal Communications Commission et al., petition-
ers, v. WNCN Listeners Guild et al.;
No. 79–825. Insilco Broadcasting Corporation et al., petitioners, v.
WNCN Listeners Guild et al.;
No. 79-826. American Broadcasting Company, Inc. et al., petition-
ers, v. WNCN Listeners Guild et al.; and

is allotted for oral argument.

OPINIONS
No. 78-972. United States, petitioner, v. Stanley Apfelbaum. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit. Judgment reversed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in the judgment. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring in the judgment with whom Mr. Jus-
tice Marshall joins.
No. 78-1088. Henry A. Kissinger, petitioner, v. Reporters Commit-
tee for Freedom of the Press et al.; and
No. 78-1217. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press et al.,
petitioners, v. Henry A. Kissinger. On writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judg-
ment affirmed in part and reversed in part. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or
decision of these cases. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the de-
cision of these cases. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in
part and dissenting in part. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens concurring
in part and dissenting in part.
No. 78–1118. Peter H. Forsham et al., petitioners, v. Patricia Rob-
erts Harris, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare et al. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Jus-
tice Marshall joins.
No. 79–97. California Retail Liquor Dealers Association, petitioner,
v. Midcal Aluminum, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the Court of
Appeal of California, Third Appellate District. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 78–1418. William E. Bloomer, Jr., petitioner, v. Liberty Mutual
Insurance Company, etc. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

500

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 17, 1980
503
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 79–797. Crown Simpson Pulp Company et al., petitioners, v.
Douglas M. Costle, Administrator, Environmental Protection Agency.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted,
judgment reversed, and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79-923. Alan L. Stein, Secretary of the Business and Trans-
portation Agency of California, appellant, v. Conference of Federal
Savings and Loan Associations et al. Appeal from the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion of NAACP Legal
Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, granted. Motion of American Savings and Loan League for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Judgment affirmed.
No. 79–996. Russell Cargill, Administrator of the Estate, Father
and Next Friend of Michael Cargill et al., appellants, v. City of
Rochester, New Hampshire. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New
Hampshire. The appeal dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 79–6075. William E. Conrad, appellant, v. Harold H. Greene,
United States District Judge, et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the District of Columbia. The appeal dismissed
for want of jurisdiction.
No. 79-1102. James L. Pickering, appellant, v. County of Erie,
New York. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. The appeal dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari denied.
310-278 0-80-58

504
MONDAY, MARCH 17, 1980
No. 79-1132. Mountain States Telephone and Telegraph Company,
appellant, v. Commissioner of Labor and Industry of Montana. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Montana. The appeal dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 79–1158. Joseph Ricco, appellant, v. Ohio. Appeal from the
Court of Appeals of Ohio, Cuyahoga County. The appeal dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-1849. Attorney General of the State of New York, peti-
tioner v. Gerald L. Shargel, Attorney in behalf of Vincent Aloi. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States of Appeals
for the Second Circuit for further consideration in light of United
States v. Apfelbaum, 445 U.S.—(1980).
No. 79–5731. Stanley Brown, petitioner, v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Tenth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appals for the Tenth Circuit granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit
for further consideration in light of the position presently asserted by
the Solicitor General in his memorandum filed February 15, 1980.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-682. John P. McGoff et al., applicants, v. Securities & Ex-
change Commission. Application for stay of order of United States
District Court for the District of Columbia entered December 12,
1979, presented to the Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court,
denied.
No. A-697. Robert J. Hudspeth, Jr., applicant, v. Mace B. Thur-
man, Jr. Application for stay addressed to Mr. Justice Marshall and
referred to the Court, denied.
No. A-720. Cecil D. Andrus, Secretary of the Interior, applicant v.
Virginia Surface Mining and Reclamation Association, Inc., et al.;
and
No. A-725. Virginia Citizens for Better Reclamation, Inc., et al.,
applicants, v. Virginia Surface Mining and Reclamation Association,
Inc., et al. Applications for stay of judgment of the United States
District Court for the Western District of Virginia, No. 78-0224-B,

MONDAY, MARCH 17, 1980
505
presented to the Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court,
granted pending the timely filing and disposition of the appeals in
this Court.
No. A-747. Federation for American Immigration Reform et al.,
applicants, v. Philip M. Klutznick, Secretary of Commerce, et al.
Application for an injunction, presented to the Chief Justice and by
him referred to the Court, denied. The motion to treat the applica-
tion as a statement as to jurisdiction, denied.
No. A-758. Halston Builders Associates et al., applicants, v. Paul
R. Kramer, etc., et al. Application for stay of judgment of the Su-
preme Court of New Jersey, presented to Mr. Justice Brennan, and
by him referred to the Court, denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun would
grant application.
No. 9, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Louisiana et al. Motion of Alabama for entry of supplemental decree
and cross-motion of the United States for entry of supplemental de-
cree are referred to the Special Master. Mr. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. 27, Original. State of Ohio, plaintiff, v. Commonwealth of Ken-
tucky. Petition for rehearing denied.
No. 79-1. American Export Lines, Inc., petitioner, v. Gilberto
Alvez et al. Motion of petitioner for leave to file supplemental brief,
after argument, granted.
No. 79-48. Cecil D. Andrus, Secretary of Interior, et al., petitioners,
v. Glover Construction Co. Motion of the Solicitor General to permit
Andrew J. Levander, Esquire, to present oral argument, pro hac vice,
granted.
No. 79-66. Peter E. Aaron, petitioner, v. Securities and Exchange
Commission. Motion of Securities Industry Association for leave to
file supplemental brief, as amicus curiae, after argument, denied.
No. 79-116. Halley I. Thomas, petitioner, v. Washington Gas
Light Company et al. Motion of the Solicitor General to permit Alan
I. Horowitz, Esquire, to present oral argument, pro hac vice, granted.
No. 79-602. Donald W. Agins et ux., appellants, v. City of Tiburon.
Motion of appellants for additional time for oral argument, or in the
alternative for divided argument, denied.
No. 79-616. Mohasco Corporation, petitioner, v. Ralph H. Silver.
Motion of the Solicitor General for divided argument granted.
No. 79–639. United States, petitioner, v. Sioux Nation of Indians
et al. Motion of Indian Law Resource Center for leave to file a brief,
as amicus curiae, granted.

MONDAY, MARCH 17, 1980

No. 79–880. Henry Kissinger et al., petitioners, v. Morton Halperin

this motion.

and Welfare, appellant, v. Cora McRae et al. Motion of Solicitor Gen-

Columbia Circuit on February 25, 1980, denied.

from the Supreme Court of Florida. In this case probable jurisdiction
noted.

forma pauperis granted. The petition for writ of certiorari in No. 79–
5949 is granted limited to Question 1 presented by the petition. The
petition for writ of certiorari in No. 79-5951 is granted. The cases are
consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argument.

TUESDAY, MARCH 18, 1980
523
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
OPINIONS
No. 78–1693. United States, petitioner, v. Glen M. Clarke, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun with whom Mr. Justice White joins.
No. 78-6386. William James Rummel, petitioner, v. W. J. Estelle,
Jr., Director, Texas Department of Corrections. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judg-
ment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Concurring opinion
by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with
whom Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Stevens join.
No. 78–1202. Vincent F. Chiarella, petitioner, 2. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sec-
ond Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Stevens. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in the
judgment. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Justice Marshall
joins.
No. 78-1472. Douglas M. Costle, Administrator, Environmental
Protection Agency, petitioner, v. Pacific Legal Foundation, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
No. 78–1588. Carol Vance, et al., appellants, v. Universal Amuse-
ment Co., Inc., et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion per curiam an-
nounced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Chief
Justice Burger with whom Mr. Justice Powell joins. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins.

525
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
OPINIONS
No. 78-1201. Mobil Oil Corporation, appellant, v. Commissioner of
Taxes of Vermont. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Vermont.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice
Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 78-572. United States Parole Commission, et al., petitioners,
v. John M. Geraghty. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr. Chief Justice
Burger, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 78–1248. GTE Sylvania, Incorporated, et al., petitioners, v.
Consumers Union of the United States, Inc., et al. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Colum-
bia Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
No. 78-904. Deposit Guaranty National Bank, Jackson, Missis-
sippi, petitioner, v. Robert L. Roper, et al. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Concurring opinion by
Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring in the judgment. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr. Justice Stewart
joins.
No. 78–1455. United States, petitioner, v. Edgar H. Gillock. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting statement by
Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Justice Powell joins.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 24, 1980
527
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-1839. ASARCO Incorporated (formerly The American
Smelting and Refining Company), appellant, v. Idaho State Tax Com-
mission. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Idaho. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Idaho for further con-
sideration in light of Mobil Oil Corporation v. Commissioner of Taxes
of Vermont, 415 U.S.—(1980).
No. 79–1143. Ringling Bros.-Barnum & Bailey Combined Shows,
Inc., appellant, v. John W. Mikos, as Property Appraiser of Sarasota
County, Florida, et al. Appeal from the District Court of Appeal of
Florida, Second District. The appeal dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question. Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Blackmun
and Mr. Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and set the
case for oral argument.
No. 79–1182. John Russo, Trustee, et al., appellants, v. Town of
East Hartford. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Connecticut. The
appeal dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari
denied.
No. 79–1284. Thomas E. Kneeland, Jr., appellant, v. New England
Merchants National Bank et al. Appeal from the United States Court
of Appeals for the First Circuit. The appeal dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-1008. Minda Satterwhite, etc., petitioner, v. City of Green-
ville, Texas. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The petition for a writ of
310-278 0-80-62

528
MONDAY, MARCH 24, 1980
certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further considera-
tion in light of United States Parole Commission v. Geraghty, 445
U.S.—(1980)—and Deposit Guaranty National Bank v. Roper, 445
U.S.-(1980).
No. 79–5649. Ida Vene Armour, petitioner, v. City of Anniston,
etc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of United
States Parole Commission v. Geraghty, 115 U.S.- (1980)—and De-
posit Guaranty National Bank v. Roper, H5 U.S.—(1980).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-735. Irving Heir, etc., et al., applicants, v. John J. Degnan,
Attorney General of New Jersey, et al. Application for stay of the
judgment of the Supreme Court of New Jersey addressed to Mr. Jus-
tice Powell and referred to the Court denied. Mr. Justice Brennan
took no part in the consideration or decision of this application.
No. A-776. Freedom Institute of America et al., applicants, v. New
Jersey. Application for stay of the orders of the Supreme Court of
New Jersey addressed to Mr. Justice Stevens and referred to the
Court denied.
No. A-784. William Harris Sharpe, applicant, v. Florida. Applica-
tion for stay and/or continued release on bond addressed to Mr. Justice
Marshall and referred to the Court denied.
No. 81, Original. Commonwealth of Kentucky, plaintiff, v. State of
Indiana et al. Report of the Special Master is received and ordered
filed. Motion of Public Service Company of Indiana, Inc. for leave to
intervene, denied. Motion of Public Service Company of Indiana,
Inc. for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Motion for
summary adoption of the Report of the Special Master is granted
and the case is remanded to the Special Master so that with the co-
operation of the parties he may prepare and submit to the Court an
appropriate form of decree.
No. 79–1203. Lucky Mc Uranium Corporation, petitioner, v. Geo-
met Exploration, Ltd. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief
in this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 79–1268. Patricia R. Harris, Secretary of Health, Education
and Welfare, appellant, v. Cora McRae et al. Motion of Alan Ernest.

MONDAY, MARCH 24, 1980
529
to be appointed as counsel for Children Unborn and Born Alive, de-
nied. Motion of Legal Defense Fund for Unborn Children for leave
to file a brief, as amicus curiae, denied.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 79-5932. John Doe and Jane Roe, appellants, v. Delaware. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Delaware. Motion of appellants for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. In this case probable
jurisdiction noted.

TUESDAY, MARCH 25, 1980
545
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
ADMISSIONS TO THE BAR ON ORAL MOTIONS
Applicant
City and State
Laura Diane Millman
New York, N.Y.
Christopher E. Hamilton
Kevin Edward O'Brien
San Francisco,
Calif.
Washington, D.C.
OPINIONS
Movant
Solicitor General
Wade H.
McCree, Jr.
Robert Marvin
Teets, Jr.
Michael William
Youdin
No. 78–1155. Joseph Vitek, etc., et al., appellants, v. Larry D.
Jones. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District
of Nebraska. Judgment affirmed as modified to conform with the sep-
arate opinion filed by Mr. Justice Powell. Mr. Justice White an-
nounced the judgment of the Court and delivered an opinion joined
by Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Powell and
Mr. Justice Stevens and joined in by Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Marshall and Mr. Justice Stevens in Part IV-B. Opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Powell concurring in part. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist joined. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
No. 78–777. United States, petitioner, v. Kenneth Crews. On writ
of certiorari to the District of Columbia Court of Appeals. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the District of Columbia Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings not inconsistent with the judgment of
this Court. Mr. Justice Brennan announced the judgment of the Court
and delivered an opinion in which Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Stevens joined and
joined by Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Stevens in Part II-D.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell concurring in part with whom Mr.
Justice Blackmun joined. Opinion by Mr. Justice White concurring in
the result in which Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist joined. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 79-421. John M. Bryant et al., petitioners, v. Ben Yellen et al.;
No. 79-425. California et al., petitioners, v. Ben Yellen et al.; and
No. 79-435. Imperial Irrigation District et al., petitioners, v. Ben
Yellen et al. One and one half hours allowed for oral argument.

for the United States, et al., as amici curiae, by special leave of Court.

et al. Argument commenced by Mr. James R. Dickens for the
petitioners and continued by Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace for the
respondents.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 31, 1980
549
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79-664. Ventura County, appellant, v. Gulf Oil Corporation.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. Judgment affirmed.
No. 79–5877. Jerry Leander Poe, appellant, v. North Carolina.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of North Carolina. The appeal dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Brennan
and Mr. Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and set the
case for oral argument.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78–1391. Chateau X, Inc., et al., petitioners, v. William H.
Andrews, District Attorney for the Fourth District of North Carolina.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of North Caro-
lina. The petition for a writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of North Carolina for further
consideration in light of Vance v. Universal Amusement Co., Inc., 445
U.S. (1980). Mr. Justice White dissents.
-
No. 79–482. Terrell Don Hutto, Director, Virginia Department of
Corrections, et al., petitioners, v. Roger Trenton Davis. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. The petition for a writ of certiorari granted. Judgment va-
cated and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit for further consideration in light of Rummel v. Estelle,
445 U.S. (1980).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 79-4. Jasper F. Williams and Eugene F. Diamond, appellants,
2. David Zbaraz, et al.;
No. 79–5. Jeffrey C. Miller, Acting Director, Illinois Department
of Public Aid, et al., appellants, v. David Zbaraz, et al.;

550
MONDAY, MARCH 31, 1980
No. 79-491. United States, appellant, v. David Zbaraz, et al.; and
No. 79–1268. Patricia R. Harris, Secretary of Health, Education,
and Welfare, appellant, v. Cora McRae, et al. Motion of the Solicitor
General to consolidate the cases for oral argument denied. Motion of
intervening appellees in No. 79-1268 for divided argument denied.
Motion of appellees in No. 79–1268 for divided argument denied. Mo-
tion of Congressman Jim Wright, et al. for leave to participate in oral
argument, as amici curiae, in No. 79-1268 denied. Motion of Coalition
for Human Justice for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, in No. 79-
1268 granted. Motion of Bergen-Passaic Health Systems Agency for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, in No. 79–1268 granted.
No. 79–669. Dawson Chemical Company, et al., petitioners, v. Rohm
and Haas Company. Motion of Chemical Manufacturers Association
for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Motion of Pharma-
ceutical Manufacturers Association for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, granted. Motion of New York Patent Law Association for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Motion of Licensing
Executives Society (U.S.A.), Inc. for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, granted. Motion of American Chemical Society for leave to file
a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Motion of National Agricultural
Chemicals Association for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, grant-
ed. Motion of Society of University Patent Administrators, et al. for
leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, granted. Motion of National Small
Business Asociation for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
Motion of National Association of Manufacturers for leave to file a
brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Motion of American Patent Law As-
sociation for leave to join in the brief, amicus curiae, of the National
Agricultural Chemicals Association denied. Motion of National
Agricultural Chemicals Association for additional time for oral ar
gument is denied, but the alternative request for divided argument is
granted.
No. 79-1258. Confederation of Iranian Students, petitioner, v.
Benjamin R. Civiletti, Attorney General of the United States. Appli-
cation for stay addressed to Mr. Justice Brennan and referred to the
Court denied. Mr. Justice Brennan would grant the application.
No. 79-5932. John Doe and Jane Roe, appellants, v. Delaware.
Motion to seal the record is granted and the parties are directed to
proceed on the original record.
No. 79–6120. Walter V. Zurosky, Jr., Edward Brazas and Matthew
Shaughnessy, petitioners, v. United States. Application for stay ad-
dressed to Mr. Justice Stewart and referred to the Court denied.

No. 78-1654. Peter Branti, as Public Defender of Rockland County,
petitioner, v. Aaron Finkel and Alan Tabakman. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judg-
ment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell in
which Mr. Justice Rehnquist joined and in Part I of which Mr. Justice
Stewart joined.
Adjourned until Monday, April 14, 1980 at 10 o'clock.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 14, 1980
573
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Before we proceed today with the regular business of the Court,
it is our sad duty to take note of the death of our beloved colleague
and friend Mr. Justice Stanley Reed.
"He served as a Justice of this Court from 1938 to 1957, after having
served as Solicitor General of the United States from 1935 to 1938.
"His death came almost 22 years after retiring from this Court, but
retirement for Justice Reed was not the end, but a continuation of his
judicial career.
"At his own request, he was assigned to sit on United States Courts
of Appeals throughout the United States, and particularly on the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
I shared the pleasant and valuable experience of sitting with him on
many cases on that Court, so I found firsthand what his colleagues of
this Court knew: that Justice Reed was a thoughtful, painstaking, able
jurist, dedicated to the American system and the Constitution. His 19
years in this Court spanned one of the most stirring periods of the
country's history and the Court's history. But whether in agreement
or dissent in cases of great importance, Mr. Justice Reed was the epi-
tome of civility.
"His career as lawyer in government was unusual, to say the least.
He was successively General Counsel of the Federal Farm Board,
General Counsel of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and Solic-
itor General of the United States before his appointment to this Court
by President Roosevelt. He lived a rich and full life in every respect.
"I speak for all the members of this Court in expressing our pro-
found sympathy to Mrs. Reed and to her family, the two sons of Mr.
Justice Reed and Mrs. Reed.
"On an appropriate occasion after the opening of the next Term of
this Court in October, the official memorial service of the Bar will be
conducted for Mr. Justice Reed in this Chamber."
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
310-278 0-80-68

574
MONDAY, APRIL 14, 1980
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79–1152. Glenn N. Hefner, etc., appellant, v. New Orleans Pub-
lic Service, Inc., et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit. The appeal dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 79–5837. Roy Glen Swink, appellant, v. Texas. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Texas. The appeal dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 79–6090. Edward Wayland, appellant, v. James B. Tiffany,
Jr., et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
First Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 79–1373. Republican National Committee, et al., appellants, v.
Federal Election Commission, et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Southern District of New York. Judgment
affirmed.
No. 79–1375. Republican National Committee, et al., appellants, v.
Federal Election Commission, et al. Appeal from the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
No. 79–6084. Maurice Savarin, appellant, v. National Bank of
Commerce Master Charge. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of
Tennessee, Western Division. The appeal dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78–1803. United States, petitioner, v. John Richard Humphries.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of
United States v. Crews, 445 U.S.- (1980).
No. 79-1041. California, petitioner, v. Robert Stanley Austin. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Department, Superior
Court of California, County of Los Angeles. The petition for writ of
certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Ap-
pellate Department, Superior Court of California, County of Los
Angeles, to consider whether its judgment is based on federal or state
constitutional grounds, or both.

for injunction and other relief addressed to Mr. Justice Brennan and
referred to the Court, denied.

AFL-CIO, Local 1-547, applicant, v. Roger W. Goubeaux, etc. Appli-

tice Marshall and by them referred to the Court, denied.

applicants, v. United States, et al. Application for stay of the order
of the United States District Court for the District of Colorado pend-
ing appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit,
presented to Mr. Justice White and by him referred to the Court, de-
nied. Mr. Justice Brennan would grant the application.

Court of Alabama addressed to Mr. Justice White and referred to the

sippi, et al. Motion for leave to file a bill of complaint granted. The
defendants are allowed sixty days in which to answer. Application
for stay of proceedings in the United States District Court for the
Southern District of Mississippi, denied.

curiae, granted.

ment of Revenue. Motion of appellant for leave to file a brief, after
argument, granted. Mr. Justice Stewart took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this motion.

ORDER ADOPTING AMENDMENTS TO THE RULES OF THE SUPREME COURT
OF THE UNITED STATES
The Rules of this Court as amended on April 14, 1980, have been
lodged with the Clerk, and it is ordered that said Rules shall become
effective on June 30, 1980, and be printed as an appendix to the United
States Reports.
It is further ordered that the Rules promulgated on June 15, 1970,
appearing in volume 398 of the United States Reports be, and they
hereby are, rescinded, but this shall not affect any proper action taken
under them before the Rules hereby adopted become effective.
ORDER PRESCRIBING RULES OF PROCEDURE FOR THE TRIAL OF MISDE-
MEANORS BEFORE UNITED STATES MAGISTRATES
It is ordered that the Rules of Procedure for the Trial of Mis-
demeanors before United States Magistrates be and they are hereby
prescribed pursuant to § 3402 of Title 18, United States Code. These
Rules shall become effective on June 1, 1980, and shall supersede the
Rules for the Trial of Minor Offenses before United States Magistrates
heretofore promulgated by this Court on January 27, 1971.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
OPINIONS
No. 78–5420. Theodore Payton, appellant, v. New York; and
No. 78–5421. Obie Riddick, appellant, v. New York. Appeals from
the Court of Appeals of New York. Judgments reversed and the cases
are remanded to the New York Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Stevens. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Chief Justice
Burger and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Rehnquist.
No. 78–1793. Winfield L. Roberts, petitioner, v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Dis-
trict of Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice.
Powell. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dissenting opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
No. 78–1756. United States, petitioner, v. Helen Mitchell, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Claims. Judgment.
reversed and the case is remanded to the Court of Claims for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White with
whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Stevens join. Mr. Chief
Jutsice Burger took no part in the decision of this case.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice

OPINIONS
No. 79–260. Cecil D. Andrus, Secretary of Interior, petitioner, v.
Idaho, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment is affirmed in part and reversed
in part and the case is remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 78-5471. Thomas W. Whalen, petitioner, v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the District of Columbia Court of Appeals. Judg-
ment reversed and the case is remanded to the District of Columbia
Court of Appeals for further proceedings not inconsistent with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Opinion by
Mr. Justice White concurring in part and concurring in the judgment.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring in the judgment. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Chief Jus-
tice Burger joins.
No. 78–1779. George D. Owen, petitioner, v. City of Independence,
Missouri, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and the case is
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Bren-
nan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr. Chief
Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Stewart, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
