MONDAY, APRIL 21, 1980
605
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78–5422. Federico Gonzalez, appellant, v. New York. Appeal
from the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New York, Second
Judicial Department. The judgment is vacated and the case is re-
manded to the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New York, Sec-
ond Judicial Department, for further consideration in light of Payton
v. New York, 445 U.S. -
-
(1980).
No. 78-5928. Dewayne Waller, appellant, v. United States.
Appeal from the District of Columbia Court of Appeals. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 79–1339. Theodore Q. Childs, appellant, v. Lucy Gant Childs.
Appeal from the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New York,
Second Judicial Department. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 79-1145. Budget Marketing, Inc., et al., appellants, v. Ken-
tucky. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Kentucky. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Stew-
art would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral argu-
ment.
No. 79-1341. Peter W. Bowman, appellant, v. Maine State Employ-
ees Appeals Board, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Judicial Court
of Maine. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 79–5946. Robert Parkins, et al., appellants, v. Illinois. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
No. 79–6094. Hector Cruz, appellant, v. New York. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
310-278 0- _72

606
MONDAY, APRIL 21, 1980
No. 79-6160. Arthur F. Jackson, appellant, v. Wisconsin. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Wisconsin. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 79-6174. Cody V. Higgins, appellant, v. Missouri. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Missouri. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 79–6050. Nancy Jewell Cross, appellant, v. Marvin Church,
et al. Appeal from the Small Claims Court, San Mateo County, Cali-
fornia, Second Judicial District. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction.
No. 79–6152. Janice Hayes, appellant, v. Valley Bank of Nevada.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Nevada. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a properly presented federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77–6769. Charles Hugh Brown, petitioner, v. Florida. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the District Court of Appeal of Florida,
First District. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the District Court of
Appeal of Florida, First District, for further consideration in light
of Payton v. New York, 445 U.S. — (1980).
No. 78–5403. Vincent Anthony Bush, petitioner, v. Florida. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the District Court of Appeal of Flor-
ida, First District. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted.
The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the District Court
of Appeal of Florida, First District, for further consideration in light
of Payton v. New York, 445 U.S. (1980).
No. 78-5471. James E. Pynes, petitioner, v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the District of Columbia Court of Appeals.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and
the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is va-
cated and the case is remanded to the District of Columbia Court of
Appeals for further consideration in light of Whalen v. United States,
445 U.S. (1980).
-
No. 78–6276. Vincent Vidal, petitioner, v. New York. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of
New York, Second Judicial Department. The motion of petitioner for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of cer-

MONDAY, APRIL 21, 1980
607
tiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New York, Second Judi-
cial Department, for further consideration in light of Payton v. New
York, 445 U.S.
(1980).
No. 78-6839. Eddie Gordon, petitioner, v. New York. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of
New York, Second Judicial Department. The motion of petitioner
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of
certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is re-
manded to the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New York,
Second Judicial Department, for further consideration in light of
Payton v. New York, 445 U.S.
(1980).
__
No. 79-326. United States, petitioner, v. Mabel Duncan, et al. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Claims.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is va-
cated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Claims
for further consideration in light of United States v. Mitchell, 445
U.S.
--
(1980).
No. 79–620. Diane Sala, petitioner, v. County of Suffolk. On peti-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further consideration in
light of Owen v. City of Independence, Missouri, 445 U.S. · (1980).
No. 79-711. Alabama, petitioner, v. James G. Davis. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment of the Court of Appeals is vacated, and that court is directed to
remand the case to the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Alabama with instructions to vacate the order denying the
petition for a writ of habeas corpus. See United States v. Munsing-
wear, 340 U.S. 36 (1950). Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 79-1178. Faymor Development Co., Inc., etc., petitioner, v.
Evelyn M. King, etc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The petition
for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sec-
ond Circuit for further consideration in light of Strycker's Bay
Neighborhood Council v. Karlen, 444 U.S. (1980). Mr. Justice
Blackmun and Mr. Justice Stevens dissent.

608
MONDAY, APRIL 21, 1980
No. 79-1312. Pennsylvania, petitioner, v. Arnold T. Henderson. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Superior Court of Pennsylvania,
Philadelphia Office. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Superior Court of Penn-
sylvania, Philadelphia Office, for further consideration in light of
Fare v. Michael C., 442 U.S. 707 (1979). Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr.
Justice Stevens dissent.
No. 79-1329. Director, Office of Workers' Compensation Programs,
United States Department of Labor, petitioner, v. Walter Tantzen,
Inc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The petition for a writ of certiorari
is granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further consideration in
light of P.C. Pfeiffer Co. v. Ford, 444 U.S. 69 (1979).
No. 79-5438. Leon Gayle, etc., petitioner, v. New York. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Division, Supreme Court
of New York, Third Judicial Department. Motion of petitioner for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of cer-
tiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Appellate
Division, Supreme Court of New York, Third Judicial Department,
for further consideration in light of Payton v. New York, 445 U.S.——
(1980).
No. 79-5853. Leon Dunagan, petitioner, v. Illinois. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the
petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, for fur-
ther consideration in light of Payton v. New York, 445 U.S.—
(1980).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-833. Coniel L. Hollidty, et al. applicants. Solomon A.
Hauptman, Trustee. The application for stay addressed to Mr. Justice
White and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-152. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael F. Waters. It
having been reported to the Court that Michael F. Waters, of Brook-
lyn, New York, has been disbarred from the practice of law by the
Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New York, First Judicial
Dept., and this Court by order of December 11, 1978, having suspended
the said Michael F. Waters from the practice of law in this Court and
directed that a rule issue requiring him to show cause why he should

MONDAY, APRIL 21, 1980
609
not be disbarred; And it appearing that the said rule was duly issued
and served upon the respondent and that the time to file a response
has expired; It is ordered that the said Michael F. Waters be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court, and that his name be stricken
from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this
Court.
No. D-157. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert B. Mitchell, Jr.
It having been reported to the Court that Robert B. Mitchell, Jr., of
Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, has been disbarred with consent from the
practice of law by the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, and this Court
by order of February 26, 1979, having suspended the said Robert B.
Mitchell, Jr. from the practice of law in this Court and directed that a
rule issue requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred;
And it appearing that the said rule was duly issued and served upon
the respondent and that the time to file a response has expired; It is
ordered that the said Robert B. Mitchell, Jr. be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court, and that his name be stricken from the
roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court.
No. D-176. In the Matter of Disbarment of David Alan Pravda.
It having been reported to the Court that David Alan Pravda, of New
York, New York, has been censured by the Appellate Division of the
Supreme Court of New York, First Judicial Dept., and this Court by
order of October 9, 1979, having suspended the said David Alan Prav-
da from the practice of law in this Court and directed that a rule issue
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred; And it
appearing that the said rule was duly issued and served upon the re-
spondent and that the time to file a response has expired; It is ordered
that the said David Alan Pravda be disbarred from the practice of law
in this Court, and that his name be stricken from the roll of attorneys
admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court.
No. D-179. In the Matter of Disbarment of Joe Merrill Kyle. It
having been reported to the Court that Joe Merrill Kyle, of Silver
Spring, Maryland, has been disbarred by consent from the practice of
law by the Court of Appeals of Maryland, and this Court by order of
October 15, 1979, having suspended the said Joe Merrill Kyle from the
practice of law in this Court and directed that a rule issue requiring
him to show cause why he should not be disbarred; And it appearing
that the said rule was duly issued and served upon the respondent and
that the time to file a response has expired; It is ordered that the said
Joe Merrill Kyle be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court,
and that his name be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to
practice before the Bar of this Court.

610
MONDAY, APRIL 21, 1980
No. D-185. In the Matter of Disbarment of Freeman D. Mitchell.
It is ordered that Freeman D. Mitchell, of Atlanta, Georgia, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 9, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Louisiana, et al. The motion of the Special Master, Walter P. Arm-
strong, Jr., for allowance of additional compensation and reimburse-
ment of expenses, as set forth in the motion, is granted, and it is
ordered that such costs be borne equally by the United States and Loui-
siana. The Court defers action at this time on the Special Master's sug-
gestion for discharge with respect to the reference of October 25, 1975
(423 U.S. 909). Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration
or decision of this motion.
No. 78-1881. Carpenters Pension Trust Fund for Northern Cali-
fornia, appellant, v. Christine Campa, et al. Motion of appellees for
attorney's fees denied.
No. 79–602. Donald W. Agins, et ux., appellants, v. City of Tiburon.
Motion of New Jersey for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, denied.
No. 79–952. Eddie C. Thomas, petitioner, v. Review Board of the
Indiana Employment Security Division. et al. Motion of Jewish Peace
Fellowship, et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, granted.
Motion of American Jewish Congress for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, granted. Motion of American Civil Liberties Union for leave to
file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Motion of Americans United for
Separation of Church and State Fund, Inc., for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, granted.
No. 79–1268. Patricia R. Harris, Secretary of Health, Education
and Welfare, appellant, v. Cora McRae, et al. Motion for reconsidera-
tion of the motion for appointment of Alan Ernest as counsel for Chil-
dren Unborn and Born Alive is denied.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 79-1260. Noel Chandler and Robert Granger, appellants. v.
Florida. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. In this case prob-
able jurisdiction noted.

ORDER
It is ordered that the call of the calendar, except for special assign-
ments, be suspended for the term upon the conclusion of the arguments
in the cases listed for hearing this week.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, April 28, 1980, until
Monday, May 12, 1980.

OPINIONS
No. 78–1840. City of Rome, et al., appellants v. United States, et
al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Columbia. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Con-
curring opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Justice Stewart
joins.
No. 79-381. Paul J. Wengler, appellant, v. Druggists Mutual In-
surance Company, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Missouri.
Judgment reversed and the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of
Missouri for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stevens concurring in the judgment. Dissenting statement by Mr. Jus-
tice Rehnquist.
No. 77–1844. City of Mobile, Alabama, et al., appellants, v. Wiley
L. Bolden, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and the case is remanded to the
310-278 0-73

622
TUESDAY, APRIL 22, 1980
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
judgment of this Court, Mr. Justice Stewart announced the judgment
of the Court and delivered an opinion in which Mr. Chief Justice
Burger, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring in the result. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall in
this case and in No. 78-357, post. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice
Brennan in this case and in No. 78-357, post.
No. 78-1261. Norman A. Carlson Director, Federal Bureau of
Prisons, et al., petitioners v. Marie Green, Administratrix of the Es-
tate of Joseph Jones, Jr. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell concur-
ring in the judgment with whom Mr. Justice Stewart joins. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Rehnquist.
No. 77-6219. Thomas Baldasar, petitioner, v. Illinois. On writ of
certiorari to the Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District. Judg-
ment reversed and the case is remanded to the Appellate Court of
Illinois, Second District for further proceedings not inconsistent with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief
Justice Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom
Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Stevens join. Concurring opinion
by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr.
Justice Stevens join. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr. Chief
Justice Burger, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 78-357. Robert R. Williams, et al., appellants, v. Leila G.
Brown, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. Judgment vacated and the case is remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in light of the decision of the
Court in No. 77-1844, City of Mobile v. Bolden, ante. Opinion per
curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Concurring state-
ment by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan in this case and in No. 77-1844, ante. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Marshall in this case and No. 77-1844, ante. Dissenting
statement by Mr. Justice White.
No. 79–105. Curtiss-Wright Corporation, petitioner, v. General
Electric Company. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment vacated and the case is
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger

ORAL ARGUMENT

FRIDAY, APRIL 25, 1980
625
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice
Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-904. Worldwide Church of God, Inc., et al., applicants, v.
Superior Court of California, County of Los Angeles (California real
party in interest). Application for stay of judgment of the Superior
Court of the State of California for the County of Los Angeles, en-
tered December 31, 1979, presented to Mr. Chief Justice Burger and
by him referred to the Court, denied. Mr. Justice Stewart took no
part in the consideration or decision of this application.

310-278 0-74



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 28, 1980
627
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice
Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79-6015. Marvin Ray Robertson, appellant, v. Texas. Appeal
from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79–1044. William C. Bush, petitioner, v. William R. Lucas. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. The petition for a writ of certiorari is granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of
Carlson v. Green, 445 U.S.-(1980).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-844. Sergey Clement Walton, applicant, v. United States.
Application for bail addressed to Mr. Justice Stevens and referred to
the Court is denied.
No. A-863. Anna Stanton Green, applicant, v. Eliot Bartholomew,
et al. Application for stay of mandate addressed to Mr. Justice Stewart
and referred to the Court is denied.
No. A-892. Peter Marcello, applicant, v. United States. Application
for bail addressed to Mr. Justice Brennan and referred to the Court is
denied.
No. D-186. In the Matter of Disbarment of David B. Cooper. It is
ordered that David B. Cooper, of Bellaire, Ohio, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-187. In the Matter of Disbarment of Leon S. Wolk. It is
ordered that Leon S. Wolk, of Woodcliff Lake, New Jersey, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-188. In the matter of Disbarment of John A. Kesler. It is
ordered that John A. Kesler, of Terre Haute, Indiana, be suspended
310-278 075

628
MONDAY, APRIL 28, 1980
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-189. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert G. Mann. It is
ordered that Robert G. Mann, of Indianapolis, Indiana, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-190. In the Matter of Disbarment of John P. Fusciello. It is
ordered that John P. Fusciello, of Colts Neck, New Jersey, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 78–1577. Sears, Roebuck and Co., petitioner, v. County of Los
Angeles and City of Compton. This case is restored to the calendar for
reargument. Mr. Justice Stewart took no part in the consideration or
decision of this order.
No. 79-45. Gerald A. Lewis, Comptroller of the State of Florida,
etc., appellant, v. BT Investment Managers, Inc., et al. Motion of ap-
pellees for leave to file a supplemental brief, after argument, granted.
No. 79-770. Environmental Protection Agency, petitioner, v. Na-
tional Crushed Stone Association, et al. Motion of the Solicitor Gen-
eral to dispense with printing the appendix granted.
No. 79-870. United States Railroad Retirement Board, appellant.
v. Gerhard H. Fritz. Motion of appellant to
dispense with printing the appendix granted.
No. 79–1637. J. P. Stevens & Co., Inc., petitioner, v. National Labor
Relations Board, et al. Application for stay of judgment of the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, presented to
Mr. Chief Justice Burger and by him referred to the Court denied.
No. 79-5515. James Ambrose Brown, petitioner, v. James P.
Mitchell, Superintendent, Virginia State Penitentiary. Motion to
schedule the petition for writ of certiorari for consideration denied.
No. 79–5780. Hoyt Weaver, petitioner, v. Robert Graham, Governor
of Florida. Motion of petitioner for appointment of counsel granted
and it is ordered that Thomas C. MacDonald, Jr., Esquire, of Tampa,
Florida is appointed to serve as counsel for petitioner in this case.

No. 78-672. Alexis I. duPont School District, et al., petitioners, v.
Brenda Evans, et al. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit denied. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Justice Stewart
and Mr. Justice Powell join. Mr. Chief Justice Burger agrees this case
merits review here but only when a full Court is available to consider
the important issues presented by the petition for certiorari. Mr.
Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of these
petitions.

OPINIONS
No. 9, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Louisiana, et al. On exceptions to Supplemental Report of the Special
Master. Exceptions to Report of Special Master overruled in part and
sustained in part. The case is returned to the Special Master for further
proceedings. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Powell concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom Mr.
Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join. Mr. Justice Marshall
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 79-253. Ray Marshall, Secretary of Labor, et al., appellants, v.
Jerrico, Inc. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Columbia. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
United States District Court for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, APRIL 29, 1980
647
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
Ordered:
ORDER
1. That the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure be, and they are,
amended by including therein amendments to Rules 4, 5, 26, 28, 30,
32, 33, 34, 37 and 45.
2. That the aforementioned amendments to the Federal Rules of
Civil Procedure shall take effect on August 1, 1980, and shall govern
all civil proceedings thereafter commenced and, insofar as just and
practicable, all proceedings then pending.
3. That subsection (e) of Rule 37 of the Federal Rules of Civil
Procedure is hereby abrogated, effective August 1, 1980.
4. That the Chief Justice be, and he hereby is, authorized to trans-
mit to the Congress the aforementioned amendments to the Federal
Rules of Civil Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Section
2072 of Title 28, United States Code. Dissenting statement by Mr.
Justice Powell with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist join.
310-278 0
-77



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 12, 1980
649
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79–492. Robert Michael Fungaroli, appellant, v. Judith Diane
Fungaroli. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of North Carolina. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Stewart would grant the petition for
a writ of certiorari.
No. 79–1233. Stuckey's Stores, Inc., etc., appellant, v. Fred
O'Chesky, etc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Mexico. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 79–1453. John Brewster, appellant, v. City of Carbondale.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 79-1474. American Amusement Company, Inc. and Harry V.
Mohney, appellants, v. Department of Revenue, State of Michigan.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Michigan. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 79-1495. Earl L. Sappington, appellant, v. Paul R. Beckert,
etc., et al. Appeal from the Superior Court of Pennsylvania, Phila-
delphia Office. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial fed-
eral question.
No. 79-1497. Catherine C. Alfree, appellant, v. Edwin W. Alfree,
Jr. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Delaware. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 79–1325. Sue Clark, appellant, v. Indiana and Lake County
Prosecutor. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Indiana. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice Blackmun would note probable jurisdiction
and set the case for oral argument.
310-278 0- -78

650
MONDAY, MAY 12, 1980
No. 79-6108. Emma Armour, et al., appellants, v. Jack P. Nix, et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
trict of Georgia. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Blackmun and Mr. Justice Stevens would dismiss the appeal for want
of jurisdiction. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
No. 79–6237. Reyna Rodrigues, appellant, v. City of Sparks, et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certi-
orari, certiorari is denied.
No. 79-6261. Joel Jaffer, appellant, v. City of Miami, etc., et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed.
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77–6595. Donald Lee Williams, petitioner, v. North Carolina.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of North Caro-
lina. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and
the petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of North Caro-
lina granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Supreme
Court of North Carolina for further consideration in light of Balda-
sar v. Illinois, 446 U.S.
(1980).
No. 79–1465. California, petitioner, v. Barry Floyd Braeseke. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California.
Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the
petition for a writ of certiorari granted, Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of California to consider whether its
judgment is based on federal or state constitutional grounds, or both.
California v. Krivda, 409 U.S. 33 (1972).
No. 79-6149. Joseph W. Scheer, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Third Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit granted. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit for further consideration in light of the position
presently asserted by the Solicitor General in his memorandum filed
April 15, 1980. The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist dissent.

MONDAY, MAY 12, 1980
651
No. 79-6182. Richard Graham, petitioner, v. New York. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Division, Supreme Court
of New York, Third Judicial Department. Motion of petitioner for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New York, Third
Judicial Department granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New York, Third Judi-
cial Department, for further consideration in light of Payton v. New
York, 445 U.S. (1980).

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
A-886. Andrew J. Melechinsky, applicant, v. United States. Appli-
cation for stay of execution of sentence, addressed to the Chief Justice
and referred to the Court, denied.
A-890. James Craig Walthal, applicant, v. Texas. Application for
stay of mandate of the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas, addressed
to Mr. Justice Marshall and referred to the Court, denied.
D-182. In the Matter of Disbarment of Leonard Saul Blondes.
Disbarment entered.
D-191. In the Matter of Disbarment of Thomas F. Schilpp. It is
ordered that Thomas F. Schilpp, of Lansdowne, Pennsylvania, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
D-192. In the Matter of Disbarment of Owen W. Crumpacker. It
is ordered that Owen W. Crumpacker, of Valparaiso, Indiana, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 78–1851. Joseph S. Harris, petitioner, v. H. Schuldt Reederei.
Respondent is invited to file a response to the petition for rehearing
within thirty days.

Company, Inc.;

ORDER
It is ordered that Alexander L. Stevas be, and he is hereby, ap-
pointed Chief Deputy Clerk of this Court, effective Monday, June 9,
1980.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from today until Monday, May 19, 1980.

MONDAY, MAY 12, 1980
OPINIONS
689
No. 78–1832. Julius T. Cuyler, Superintendent, etc., et al., peti-
tioners, v. John Sullivan. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Powell. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in Part III of
the opinion and in the result. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall con-
curring in part and dissenting in part.
No. 79-488. General Telephone Company of the Northwest, Inc.,
et al., petitioners, v. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice White.
Dissenting statement by Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Powell,
Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 78–1076. Rhode Island, petitioner, v. Thomas J. Innis. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Rhode Island. Judgment va-
cated and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Rhode Island for
further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Concurring statement by Mr. Justice
White. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurring in the judg-
ment. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr.
Justice Brennan joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 79-1. American Export Lines, Inc., petitioner, v. Gilberto Al-
vez, et al. On writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New York.
Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Brennan announced the judgment
of the Court and an opinion in which Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Blackmun and Mr. Justice Stevens join. Mr. Chief Justice Burger
concurs in the judgment. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell concurring in
the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with
whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 78-1557. Nachman Corporation, petitioner, v. Pension Benefit
Guaranty Corporation, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens announced by Mr. Chief Justice.
Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr.
Justice White, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell.
Adjourned until Monday, May 19, 1980 at 10 o'clock.
☑



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 19, 1980
691
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79-1169. Sanford J. Berger, appellant, v. Bertine M. Berger.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Cuyahoga County. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari is denied.
No. 79–1508. Thomas E. Brown, appellant, v. United Automobile,
Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of America, UAW,
et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 79-6305. Robert Di Falco, appellant, v. Commissioner of In-
ternal Revenue. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 79-6328. Lyle H. Prenzler, appellant, v. R. Keith Pike, et al.
Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Fourth Appellate
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of cer-
tiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 79–1434. Gary Mandel, Michael DeVito and Theodore Buck-
ley, appellants, v. New York. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of
New York. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of cer-
tiorari, certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart
and Mr. Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and set the
case for oral argument.
310-278 0- -81

692
MONDAY, MAY 19, 1980
No. 79-1513. Michael Herbert Dengler, appellant, v. Attorney Gen-
eral of Minnesota. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Minnesota. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION:
No. 79–1156. G. William Miller, Secretary of the Treasury, et al.,
petitioners, v. Castlewood International Corp. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
The petition for a writ of certiorari is granted. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Cir-
cuit for further consideration in light of California Retail Liquor
Dealers Assn. v. Midcal Aluminum, 445 U.S. — (1980).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-969. William Andrews, applicant, v. Lawrence Morris, War-
den of the Utah State Prison. Application for stay of execution of
sentence of death, presented to Mr. Justice White and by him referred
to the Court, granted pending the timely filing and disposition of a
petition for a writ of certiorari.
No. 79–1738. Richard Nixon, petitioner, v. A. Ernest Fitzgerald.
Motion of petitioner to expedite consideration of the petition for a writ
of certiorari denied. Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion.
No. 79-1752. Janice Adams, etc., et al., applicant, v. United States,
et al. Application for stay of the judgment of the United States Court
of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, addressed to Mr. Justice Rehnquist
and referred to the Court, denied.
No. 79-1763. Chlorine Institute, Inc., et al., petitioners. v. Occupa-
tional Safety & Health Administration. et al. Application for stay of
the mandate of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Cir-
cuit (No. 79-2703), presented to Mr. Justice Powell and by him re-
ferred to the Court, granted except as to the employers' obligation to
provide respirators to employees exposed to chlorine concentrations in
excess of 1 ppm, pending disposition of the petition for writ of cer-
tiorari.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 79-1320. Raymond Kassel, et al., appellants, v. Consolidated
Freightways Corporation of Delaware. Appeal from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. In this case probable
jurisdiction noted.

MONDAY, MAY 19, 1980
CERTIORARI GRANTED
693
No. 79-880. Henry Kissinger, et al., petitioners, v. Morton Hal-
perin, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit granted. Mr. Justice
Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 79–1336. Chicago and North Western Transportation Com-
pany, petitioner, v. Kalo Brick & Tile Company. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Iowa granted.
No. 79-5269. Robert Edwards, petitioner, v. Arizona. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona granted, limited to
Question 1 presented by the petition.
No. 79–6027. Raymond Wood, et al., petitioners, v. Georgia. Mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Georgia granted.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 78–492. Charles H. Nevett, et al., petitioners, v. Lawrence G.
Sides, etc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.
No. 79-1175. Wm. T. Burnett & Company, Inc., petitioner, v.
General Tire & Rubber Company. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied.

Appeal of Florida, Third District, denied.

Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied.
No. 79-1245. Anthony Acavino, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-

the Third Circuit denied.
No. 79-1253. Operating Engineers Pension Trust, petitioner, v.

MONDAY, MAY 19, 1980

for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana denied. Dis-

and Mr. Justice Marshall join.

OPINIONS
No. 78-1522. Cecil D. Andrus. Secretary of the Interior, petitioner,
v. Utah. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 79-424. Board of Regents of the University of the State of
New York, et al., petitioners, v. Mary Tomanio. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens concurring in the
result. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr.
Justice Marshall joins.
No. 78–6899. Robert Franklin Godfrey, petitioner, v. Georgia.
On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia. Judgment, in-
sofar as it leaves standing the petitioner's death sentences, is reversed
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Georgia for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the judgment of this Court. Mr. Justice
Stewart announced the judgment of the Court and delivered an
opinion in which Mr. Justice Blackmun. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr.
Justice Stevens join. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall concurring in

MONDAY, MAY 19, 1980
709
the judgment with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins. Dissenting opin-
ion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
White with whom Mr. Justice Rhenquist joins.
No. 78-6020. Michael M. Busic, petitioner, v. United States; and
No. 78-6029. Anthony LaRocca, Jr., petitioner, v. United States.
On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. Judgments reversed and cases remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Concurring opinion by
Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice.
Stevens joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
No. 79–465. Navarro Savings Association, petitioner, v. Lawrence
F. Lee, Jr., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Powell announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
No. 65, Original. State of Texas, plaintiff, v. State of New Mexico.
On exceptions to Report to Special Master. Opinion per curiam an-
nounced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Upon consideration of the Re-
port filed October 15, 1979, by Senior Judge Jean S. Breitenstein,
Special Master, and the Exceptions thereto, and on consideration of
briefs and oral argument thereon,
It is adjudged, ordered, and decreed that all Exceptions are over-
ruled, the Report is in all respects confirmed, and the ruling of the
Special Master on the "1947 condition" as that term appears in Arts.
II (g) and III (a) of the Pecos River Compact is approved. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MAY 27, 1980
715
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice.
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 79-1101. Catalano, Inc., et al., petitioners, v. Target Sales, Inc.,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion per curiam.
No. 79–1294. Patricia R. Harris, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, appellant, v. Awilda Santiago Rosario, et al. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the District of Puerto Rico.
Judgment reversed and case is remanded to the United States District
Court for the District of Puerto Rico for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan and Mr. Justice Blackmun would note probable juris-
diction and set the case for oral argument. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79-1340. Hodges Transfer Company, Inc., et al., appellants, v.
Alabama Public Service Commission, et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Alabama. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 79-1606. James E. Carter, Jr., appellant, v. City of Kansas
City, Missouri. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Missouri, West-
ern District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 79–1549. Rosemary Bayolo Geeck, et al., appellants, v. City of
New Orleans, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The
310-278 0- -83

716
TUESDAY, MAY 27, 1980
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr.
Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Powell would note probable juris-
diction and set the case for oral argument.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-6891. Freddie F. Davis, petitioner, v. Georgia. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia granted. Judgment
vacated insofar as it leaves undisturbed the death penalty imposed
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Georgia for further con-
sideration in light of Godfrey v. Georgia, 446 U.S.—— (1980).
No. 79-1243. David R. Harris, Superintendent, Greenhaven Cor-
rectional Facility, et al.. petitioners, c. Fernando Bermudez, et al. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit. Motions of respondents for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis granted and the petition for a writ of certiorari ♥
granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further consideration in
light of Cuyler v. Sullivan, 446 U.S.——— (1980).
No. 79-1462. Robert McGuire, individually and as Police Com-
missioner of the City of New York, petitioner, e. Charles W. Leigh
and Leonard Allen. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The petition for a
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for
further consideration in light of Board of Regents of the University of
the State of New York v. Tomanio, 446 U.S. (1980).
No. 79-1565. Missouri, petitioner, v. William Scott Sours. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Missouri. Motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
a writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Supreme Court of Missouri for further consideration in light of
Whalen v. United States, 445 U.S. (1980).

vacated insofar as it leaves undisturbed the death penalty imposed

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-941. Edwin R. Egbert, applicant, v. Kansas. The application
for stay of the mandate of the Supreme Court of Kansas, addressed to
Mr. Justice Brennan and referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-979. Board of Education of the School District of the City of
Detroit, Michigan, et al., applicants, c. William G. Milliken, Governor
of Michigan, et al. The application for stay of the mandate of the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit (case Nos. 78-
1597, 78-1598 and 79-1005), presented to Mr. Justice Stewart and by
him referred to the Court, is denied. The order entered by Mr. Justice
Stewart on May 14, 1980 is vacated.
No. D-193. In the Matter of Disbarment of Fred L. Leach. It is
ordered that Fred L. Leach, of Amarillo, Texas, be suspended from the
practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be dis-
barred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 79–816. Potomac Electric Power Company, petitioner, v. Direc-
tor, Office of Workers' Compensation Programs, United States Depart-
ment of Labor, et al. Motion of petitioner to dispense with printing the
appendix is granted.
No. 79-6370. Albert Able and Betty Able, appellants, v. Delaware.
Motion of appellants to seal the record is granted.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 79–1380. Patricia R. Harris, Secretary of Health and Humanı
Services, appellant, v. Charles Edward Wilson, et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.
In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.

The Court will take a recess from today until Monday, June 2, 1980.

OPINIONS
Wade H.
McCree, Jr.
No. 79-5601. Carlos Rivera Gomez, petitioner, v. Astol Calero
Toledo. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the First Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Concurring
statement by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
No. 79–305. United States, petitioner, v. J. Lee Havens. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins and joined in Part I
by Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 78–1821. United States, petitioner, v. Sylvia L. Mendenhall.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the judgment of
this Court. Mr. Justice Stewart announced the judgment of the Court
and delivered an opinion in which Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins. Mr.

740
TUESDAY, MAY 27, 1980
Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Blackmun, and Mr. Justice Powell!
join all but Part II-A of this opinion. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Powell concurring in part and concurring in the judgment with whom
Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Blackmun join. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice Stevens join.
No. 78–1918. Adlene Harrison, etc., et al., petitioners, v. PPG In-
dustries, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun
concurring in the result. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 79–48. Cecil D. Andrus, Secretary of the Interior, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Glover Construction Company. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart.
Adjourned until Monday, June 2, 1980 at 10 o'clock.
Х

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 2, 1980
741
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice
White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice
Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
Mr. Justice Brennan said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by Mr. Justice
Brennan, filed with the Clerk and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 79–912. Edward V. Hanrahan, et al., petitioners, v. Iberia
Hampton, et al.; and
No. 79-914. Marlin Johnson, et al., petitioners, v. Iberia Hampton,
et al. On petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Motion of Fraternal Order of
Police of the State of Illinois in case No. 79-912 for leave to file a brief,
as amicus curiae, granted. Motions of respondents for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis are granted. Petitions for writs of certiorari
are granted, limited to the question of the propriety of the award of
attorneys' fees by the Court of Appeals, and the judgment is re-
versed insofar as it awarded attorneys' fees to the respondents and
the cases are remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. In all other re-
spects, the petitions for writs of certiorari are denied. Opinion per
curiam. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell concurring in part and dis-
senting in part with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist join. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of these
cases.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79–1295. McKeesport Area School District, appellant, v. Penn-
sylvania Department of Education. Appeal from the Commonwealth
Court of Pennsylvania. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice White
with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins. Mr. Justice
Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral
argument.
310-2780-85

742
MONDAY, JUNE 2, 1980
No. 79–1563. Yakima County Deputy Sheriff's Association, appel-
lant, v. Board of Commissioners for Yakima County, Washington,
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Washington. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 79–1608. Peter Y. Taylor, Jr., etc., appellant, v. Wisconsin Tax
Appeals Commission, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Wis-
consin. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 79–6393. Jane Doe, et al., appellants, v. Edward M. Sears. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 79–6219. Signa Nelson, appellant, v. State Accident Insurance
Fund. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Oregon. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is de-
nied. Mr. Justice Stevens would not probable jurisdiction and set the
case for oral argument.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79–6290. Glen D. Dupris, petitioner, v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit. Motion of Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe of Chey-
enne River Reservation for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae,
granted. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and the petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the United States District Court for the Dis-
trict of South Dakota (Central Division) to consider the question of
mootness.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-946. Barbara Blum, Commissioner of New York State Dept.
of Social Services, applicant, v. Ethel Caldwell, etc., et al. The appli-
cation to stay the injunction of the United States District Court for
the Northern District of New York, entered December 3, 1979, ad-
dressed to Mr. Justice Stevens and referred to the Court, is denied.

MONDAY, JUNE 2, 1980
743
No. 79-1266. Charles W. Steadman, petitioner, v. Securities and
Exchange Commission. Motion of petitioner to dispense with printing
the appendix is granted.
No. 79-1457. International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers,
AFL-CIO, Local 1969, et al., petitioners, v. Rebecca Bise, et al. The
Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the
views of the United States.
No. 79–1617. Department of Transportation of the State of Okla-
homa, petitioner, v. Mrs. C. V. Pile. The Solicitor General is invited
to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 79–1791. Larry C. Flynt, petitioner, v. Georgia. The applica-
tion for stay of execution and enforcement of the mandate of the Court
of Appeals of Georgia, presented to Mr. Justice Powell and by him
referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant the application.
No. 79–1839. Frederick John Fazio and Joseph Henry Cusanelli,
petitioners, v. United States. The application for stay of the mandate
of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, addressed
to Mr. Justice Brennan and referred to the Court, is denied.
CERTIORARI DENIED

The Court will take a recess from today until Monday, June 9, 1980.

OPINIONS
763
No. 78–1862. Fred N. Walker, petitioner, v. Armco Steel Corpora-
tion. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Tenth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
No. 79–198. Supreme Court of Virginia, et al., appellants, v. Con-
sumers Union of the United States, Inc., et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia. Judgment
vacated insofar as it awarded attorneys' fees and case remanded to the
United States District Court for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Mr.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 79-66. Peter E. Aaron, petitioner, v. Securities and Exchange
Commission. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Second Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Opinion by Mr. Justice Black-
mun concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 78–1815. Cecil D. Andrus, Secretary of Interior, petitioner, v.
Shell Oil Company, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Mr. Chief Justice Burger announced by Mr. Justice Brennan.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 9, 1980
769
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79-185. Consumers Union of United States, Inc., et al., appel-
lants, v. Virginia State Bar, et al. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Eastern District of Virginia. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the United States District Court for the Eastern
District of Virginia for further consideration in light of Supreme
Court of Virginia v. Consumers Union of the United States, Inc., 446
U.S. (1980). Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
No. 79-1597. Canal Keyhea, appellant, v. J. J. Enomoto, Director,
Department of Corrections for the State of California, et al. Appeal
from the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari is denied.
No. 79–6443. Joseph Profit, appellant, v. City of Niagara Falls,
New York, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 79-6496. Dalton H. Petrea, appellant, v. Josephine S. Petrea.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Delaware. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79-5518. Andre L. McShan, petitioner, v. Georgia. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Georgia. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Georgia granted. Judg-
310-278 087

770
MONDAY, JUNE 9, 1980
ment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals of Georgia
for further consideration in light of United States v. Mendenhall, 446
U.S. — (1980).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-953. Clifford Dixon Noe, applicant, v. United States. The
application for bail, addressed to Mr. Justice Marshall and referred
to the Court, is denied.
No. A-981. Thomas Buzzanca, applicant, v. United States. The
application for bail, addressed to Mr. Justice Brennan and referred
to the Court, is denied.
No. A-1013. Walnut Properties, Inc., applicant, v. Long Beach
City Council. The application to stay execution of the decision of the
Long Beach City Council, dated March 9, 1978, addressed to Mr.
Justice Stewart and referred to the Court, is denied.
No. D-194. In the Matter of Disbarment of Howard W. Amos.
It is ordered that Howard W. Amos, of Worthington, Ohio, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 83, Original. State of Maryland, et al., plaintiff, v. State of
Louisiana. Motion of the United States for leave to intervene is re-
ferred to the Special Master. The Report of the Special Master is re-
ceived and ordered filed. Exceptions, if any, with supporting briefs to
the Report of the Special Master may be filed by the parties within 30
days. Reply briefs, if any, to such exceptions may be filed within 30
days.
No. 79–770. Environmental Protection Agency, petitioner, v. Na-
tional Crushed Stone Association, et al. Motion of respondents for
divided argument granted.
No. 79–816. Potomac Electric Power Company, petitioner, v.
Director, Office of Workers' Compensation Programs, United States
Department of Labor, et al. Motion of Solicitor General for divided
argument granted.
No. 79-1128. Montana, et al., petitioners, v. United States, et al.
Motion of respondents for additional time for oral argument granted
and fifteen additional minutes are allotted for that purpose. Motion of
petitioners for additional time for oral argument granted and fifteen
additional minutes are allotted for that purpose.
No. 79–1388. Karl J. Kirchberg, appellant, v. Joan Paillot Feen-
stra, et al. Motion of Rudolph R. Schoemann, Esquire, to permit

MONDAY, JUNE 9, 1980
771
Alan F. Schoenberger, Esquire, of New Orleans, Louisiana, to present
oral argument pro hac vice granted.
No. 79–5269. Robert Edwards, petitioner, v. Arizona. Motion for
appointment of counsel granted and it is ordered that Michael J.
Meehan, Esquire, of Tucson, Arizona is appointed to serve as counsel
for petitioner in this case.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 79–404. United States, petitioner, v. Jesus E. Cortez and Pedro
Hernandez-Loera. Motion of respondents for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 79-1344. Michael M., petitioner, v. Superior Court of Sonoma
County (California, Real Party in Interest). Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the Supreme Court of California granted.
No. 79–1404. Pennhurst State School and Hospital, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Terri Lee Halderman, et al.;
No. 79–1408. Mayor of City of Philadelphia, et al., petitioners, v.
Terri Lee Halderman, et al.;
No. 79-1414. Pennsylvania Association for Retarded Citizens,
et al., petitioners, v. Pennhurst State School and Hospital, et al.;
No. 79-1415. Commissioners and Mental Health/Mental Retar-
dation Administrators for Bucks County, et al., petitioners, v. Terri
Lee Halderman, et al.; and
No. 79-1489. Pennhurst Parents-Staff Association, petitioner, v.
Terri Lee Halderman, et al. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit granted, except
as to Question 3, presented in petitions Nos. 79–1404 and 79–1489.
Counsel are also requested to brief and argue the following question:
Does 42 U.S.C. § 1983 provide a private remedy to enforce the pro-
visions of the Developmentally Disabled Assistance and Bill of Rights
Act, 42 U.S.C. § 6000 et seq.? The cases are consolidated and a total
of two hours is allotted for oral argument.
CERTIORARI DENIED

the Ninth Circuit denied.

OPINIONS
No. 79–289. Prune Yard Shopping Center and Fred Sahadi, appel-
lants, v. Michael Robins, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
California. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Opinion by Mr. Justice
White concurring in part and concurring in the judgment. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Powell concurring in part and concurring in the judgment
with whom Mr. Justice White joins. Statement by Mr. Justice Black-
mun concurring in all but one sentence of the opinion.
No. 79-521. Consumer Product Safety Commission, et al., peti-
tioners, v. GTE Sylvania, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
No. 79-45. Gerald A. Lewis, Comptroller of the State of Florida,
etc., appellant, v. BT Investment Managers, Inc., et al. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the Northern District of Florida.
Judgment affirmed insofar as it declares unconstitutional the chal-
lenged portions of Florida's Regulatory Reform Act of 1976 § 659.141
(1) and enjoins their enforcement. That portion of the judgment that
relates to the constitutionality of the Act vacated, and case remanded
to the United States District Court for the Northern District of
Florida for further proceedings in conformity with opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

792
MONDAY, JUNE 9, 1980
No. 79–192. New York Gaslight Club, Inc., et al., petitioners, v.
Cidni Carey. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Blackmun. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Statement
by Chief Justice Burger concurring except in footnote 6 of the opinion.
Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
No. 79–383. F. W. Standefer, petitioner, v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Cir-
cuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
No. 5, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
California. On Exception to the Report of the Special Master. The
exception of the State of California to the Report of the Special Mas-
ter is overruled. The Special Master shall prepare a proposed form
of decree consistent with the opinion of this Court and present it to
this Court for entry in due course. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Bur-
ger. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this case.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JUNE 10, 1980
801
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice
White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice
Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
Applicant
ADMISSION TO THE BAR ON ORAL MOTION
Movant
Michele L. Odorizzi
City and State
Chicago, Ill.
OPINIONS
Mr. Justice John
Paul Stevens
No. 78-6809. Dennis Seay Jenkins, petitioner, v. Charles Anderson,
Warden. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Powell. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment.
Statement by Mr. Justice Stewart concurring in the judgment, agree-
ing with all but Part II of the opinion of the Court, and with Part I
of the concurring opinion of Mr. Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
No. 79–602. Donald W. Agins, et ux., appellants, v. City of Tiburon.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell.
No. 79–81. Thomas E. Coffy, petitioner, v. Republic Steel Corp.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case is remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Marshall.
No. 79–509. Exxon Corporation, appellant, v. Wisconsin Depart-
ment of Revenue. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Wisconsin.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Justice
Stewart took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 78-630. Washington, et al., appellants, v. Confederated Tribes
of the Colville Indian Reservation, et al.; Washington, appellant, v.
United States, et al.; and
No. 78-60. Confederated Tribes of the Colville Indian Reservation,
et al., appellants, v. Washington, et al. Appeals from the United States
District Court for the Eastern District of Washington. Judgment in
No. 78-630 reversed in part and affirmed in part and cases remanded to
319-278 0- -89

802
TUESDAY, JUNE 10,
1980
the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Washing-
ton for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan
concurring in part and dissenting in part, with whom Mr. Justice
Marshall joins. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart concurring in part and
dissenting in part. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist concurring and
dissenting. Judgment in No. 78-60 affirmed.
No. 73, Original. State of California, plaintiff, v. State of Nevada.
On Exceptions to the Report of the Special Master. The exceptions of
the State of Nevada to the Report of the Special Master are overruled
and Report and Recommendations of the Special Master approved and
adopted except insofar as those recommendations would allow Cali-
fornia's Second Amended Complaint and permit proceedings relating
to the ownership of disputed lands on the California-Nevada boundary.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan.
Adjourned until Monday, June 16, 1980 at 10 o'clock.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-1080. Anthony DeVingo, et al., applicants, v. New Jersey.
Application for stay of trial court proceedings, presented to Mr.
Justice Brennan and by him referred to the Court, denied.
