(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 16, 1980
805
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 79-1377. Charles Anderson, Warden, petitioner, v. Glenn
Charles. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting state-
ment by Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79–843. Exxon Corporation, appellant, v. South Carolina Tax
Commission. Appeal from the Supreme Court of South Carolina. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr.
Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for
oral argument. Mr. Justice Stewart took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
No. 79-1588. Federation for American Immigration Reform, et al.,
appellants, v. Philip M. Klutznick, Secretary of Commerce, et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Columbia. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 79–1615. Grover C. Hall, appellant, v. California, et al. Ap-
peal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari is denied.
No. 79–1678. Mitzi S. Briggs, appellant, v. California, ex rel. De-
partment of Parks and Recreation. Appeal from the Court of Appeal
of California, First Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for
310-278 0-91

806
MONDAY, JUNE 16, 1980
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 79–6489. Millicent Linden, appellant, v. New York. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari is denied.
No. 79–1670. Avis Rent-A-Car Systems, Inc., appellant, v. Charlie
Vining, et ux. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION:
No. 78–1531. Gayle M. Franzen, et al., petitioners, v. Eddie Allen.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Seventh Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for a writ of certiorari
is granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of Jenkins v. Anderson, 447 U.S.— (1980).
No. 79–1435. Mahoning Women's Center, petitioner, v. Jack C.
Hunter, etc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The petition for a writ
of certiorari is granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of New York Gaslight Club v. Carey., 447 U.S.—
(1980) and Supreme Court of Virginia v. Consumers Union of the
United States, Inc., 446 U.S.- (1980). Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Jus-
tice White, Mr. Justice Rehnquist and Mr. Justice Stevens dissent.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-994. Machinists Non-Partisan Political League, applicant,
v. Federal Election Commission. The application for stay of execution
and enforcement of the order of the United States District Court for
the District of Columbia, No. 79-0291, entered January 30, 1980, pre-
sented to the Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
The order entered by the Chief Justice on May 23, 1980 is vacated.
No. A-1053. Burlington Northern, Inc., et al., applicants, v. Mis-
souri-Kansas-Texas Railroad Co., et al. The application for an order
to vacate the stay entered by the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit, case No. 80-1523, entered May 30, 1980, presented
to Mr. Justice Powell and by him referred to the Court, is denied.

MONDAY, JUNE 16, 1980
807
No. 9, Original. United States of American, plaintiff, v. State of
Louisiana, et al. The petition for rehearing of the order of the Court
entered April 28, 1980 is denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in
the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 79–1690. Wayne A. Stanton, individually and as Administra-
tor of the Indiana Department of Public Welfare, petitioner, v. Eliza-
beth Brown, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this
case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 79-1909. California, petitioner, v. Michael Musante. The ap-
plication for stay addressed to Mr. Justice White and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. 79–5903. H. L., etc., appellant, v. Scott M. Matheson, et al. The
motion for reconsideration of the motion for appointment of Alan
Ernest as counsel for Children Unborn and Born Alive is denied.
APPEALS JURISDICTION POSTPONED
No. 79–678. San Diego Gas & Electric Company, appellant, v. City
of San Diego, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California,
Fourth Appellate District. Further consideration of the question of
jurisdiction is postponed to the hearing of the case on the merits.
No. 79–1689. United States, appellant, v. Hubert L. Will, et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
trict of Illinois. Further consideration of the question of jurisdiction
is postponed to the hearing of the case on the merits. The motion of the
Solicitor General to consolidate this case with No. 79-983, Will v.
United States, for briefing and oral argument is granted. A total of one
and one half-hours is allotted for oral argument.

the consideration or decision of this petition.

No. 79-6612. Norman C. Gray, Jr., petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Third Circuit denied.
No. 79–6618. David Lee Huguley, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 79–6625. Richard Stephen Comeaux, petitioner, v. United
States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 79-6629. Jodene Lee Carnes, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 79–6637. Donald Phillip Lenz, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit denied.
No. 79–1352. Hart Book Stores, Inc., et al., petitioners, v. Rufus
Edmisten, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan
and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant the petition for certiorari, re-
verse the judgment of the Court of Appeals and reinstate the judg-
ments of July 21, 1978 entered in the United States District Court for
the Western District of North Carolina and of April 21, 1978 entered in
the United States District Court for the Eastern District of North
Carolina declaring unconstitutional N.C.G.S. Sections 14–202.10 to .12.
No. 79–1605. J. C. Moody, etc., petitioner, v. John P. McNamara.
Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit denied.
No. 79-1723. Lester Sutker, etc., petitioner, v. Illinois State Dental
Society, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Court of
Illinois, First District, denied. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in
the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 79-6276. Gladys Fisher, etc., petitioner, v. John R. Reiser,
Chairman of Nevada Industrial Commission, et al. Petition for writ of

MONDAY, JUNE 16, 1980
817
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
denied. Mr. Justice Powell would grant certiorari.
No. 79–6470. Raymond Lee Franklin, petitioner, v. Georgia. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia denied.
Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Mar-
shall.
No. 79-6614. Wilburn Dobbs, petitioner, v. Joseph S. Hopper,
Warden. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Superior Court of Tatt-
nall County, Georgia denied. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITIONS FOR WRITS OF HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 79–6639. Joseph E. Harris, petitioner v. Margaret Hambrick,
Warden; and
No. 79-6669. Anthony Ivory Battle, petitioner, v. Robert J.
Christensen, Warden. Motions for leave to file petitions for writs of
habeas corpus denied.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF MANDAMUS
No. 79-6546. Shiloh Harry Theriault, petitioner, v. Frederick
Silber, et al. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of mandamus
denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 77–6219. Thomas Baldasar, petitioner, v. Illinois;
No. 79-1141. Miguel Angel Mora, petitioner, v. Florida;
No. 79-1309. Carl Michael Seibert, petitioner, v. D. T. Baptist,
District Director of Internal Revenue Service, et al.;
No. 79–1468. Frieda Seyfarth, petitioner, v. Ivar Lovret;
No. 79–1495. Earl L. Sappington, appellant, v. Paul R. Beckert,
etc. et al.:
No. 79-6264. Edward Dean Christensen, petitioner, v. Commis-
sioner of Internal Revenue; and
No. 79-6417. John James Turner, petitioner, v. Robert Graham,
Governor, et al. Petitions for rehearing denied.
No. 79-1347. Stanley H. Spencer, petitioner, v. Greyhound Lines,
Inc., et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed further herein
in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for rehearing is denied.

The Court will take a recess from today until Monday, June 23, 1980.

MONDAY, JUNE 16, 1980
OPINIONS
833
No. 79–5010. Alphonse Bifulco, petitioner, v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit with instructions to vacate
the special parole term that was imposed upon petitioner. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Blackmun. Concurring opinion by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with whom Mr.
Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 79-421. John M. Bryant, et al., petitioners, v. Ben Yellen,
et al.;
No. 79–425. California, et al., petitioners, v. Ben Yellen, et al.; and
No. 79-435. Imperial Irrigation District, et al., petitioners, v. Ben
Yellen, et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment is reversed with respect to
those lands that were irrigated on June 25, 1929, and with respect to
which the District has been adjudicated to have a perfected water right
as of that date. Judgment is otherwise vacated and case remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice White.
No. 78–6885. Flynn Noye Hicks, petitioner, v. Oklahoma. On writ
of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Okla-
homa for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Rehnquist.
No. 79–5364. Darnell Brown, petitioner, v. Louisiana. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of Louisiana for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the judgment of this Court. Mr. Justice
Brennan announced the judgment of the Court and delivered an opin-
ion in which Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr.
Justice Blackmun join. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell concurring in
the judgment with whom Mr. Justice Stevens joins. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and
Mr. Justice White join.
No. 79–121. United States, petitioner, v. Billy Gale Henry. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Justice White joins. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

834
MONDAY, JUNE 16, 1980
No. 79–136. Sidney A. Diamond, Commissioner of Patents and
Trademarks, petitioner, v. Ananda M. Chakrabarty. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice White, Mr.
Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice Powell joins.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
OPINIONS
No. 79–677. Reeves, Inc., petitioner, v. William Stake, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Black-
mun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice White, and Mr. Justice Stevens join.
No. 78–1845. Illinois, petitioner, v. John M. Vitale. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of Illinois for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with whom
Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, and Mr. Justice Marshall
join.
Adjourned until Friday, June 20, 1980 at 10 o'clock.

FRIDAY, JUNE 20, 1980
841
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
OPINIONS
No. 78-6621. Gilbert Franklin Beck, petitioner, v. Alabama. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Alabama. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Alabama for
further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall concurring in the judgment.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Justice
White joins.
No. 79–67. William Walter, petitioner, v. United States; and
No. 79-148. Arthur Randall Sanders, Jr., et al., petitioners, v.
United States. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgments reversed and cases remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further
proceedings in conformity with the judgment of this Court. Mr.
Justice Stevens announced the judgment of the Court and delivered
an opinion in which Mr. Justice Stewart joined. Opinion by Mr.
Justice White concurring in part and in the judgment with whom Mr.
Justice Brennan joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun
with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr.
Justice Rehnquist join. Statement by Mr. Justice Marshall concurring
in the judgment.
No. 79-134. Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc.,
appellant, v. Public Service Commission of New York. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of New York. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals of New York for further proceedings
not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Powell. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins as to
Parts I and II.
No. 79-565. Central Hudson Gas & Electric Corporation, appel-
lant, v. Public Service Commission of New York. Appeal from the
Court of Appeals of New York. Judgment reversed and case remanded
310-278 0
-95

842
FRIDAY, JUNE 20, 1980
to the Court of Appeals for New York for further proceedings not
inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Powell. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Justice Brennan
joins. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with whom Mr.
Justice Brennan joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
No. 79-672. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Retail
Store Employees Union, Local 1001, etc. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit with directions to enforce
the National Labor Relations Board's order. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Powell. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring in Parts I and
II of the Court's opinion. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice
White and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 79–1082. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Inter-
national Longshoremen's Association, AFL-CIO, et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Mar-
shall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger with whom
Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens
join.
No. 79–703. Bernard Carey, etc., appellant, v. Roy Brown, et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Cir-
cuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice
Blackmun join.
Adjourned until Monday, June 23, 1980 at 10 o'clock.

MONDAY, JUNE 23, 1980
843
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79-5080. Archie W. Willeford, petitioner, v. W. J. Estelle, Jr.,
Director, Texas Department of Corrections. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Cir-
cuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and
the petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Cir-
cuit for further consideration in light of Hicks v. Oklahoma, 447
U.S.—
(1980).
No. 79-5145. George Eddie Sam, petitioner, v Oklahoma. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Okla-
homa. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and the petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal
Appeals of Oklahoma granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma for further considera-
tion in light of Hicks v. Oklahoma, 447 U.S.
(1980).
No. 79-5184. Leonel Laurel, petitioner, v. United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Mction of petitioner for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis is granted. Treating the motion for leave to
file and the petition for a writ of mandamus as a petition for a writ of
certiorari, certiorari is granted. The order is vacated and the case
is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit for further consideration in light of Bifulco v. United States,
447 U.S.
(1980).
No. 79–5267. Antonio Perez, petitioner, v. Louie L. Wainwright,
Secretary, Florida Department of Offender Rehabilitation. On poti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
310-278 0-96

844
MONDAY, JUNE 23, 1980
pauperis and the petition i
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of the decision in
Cuyler v. Sullivan, 446 U.S.
(1980) (slip op., at 7-9),
on the application of the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments to claims
arising from the conduct of retained counsel.
,
No. 79-5338. Bernard H. Bynum, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit for further consideration in light of Bifulco v.
United States, 447 U.S.
(1980).
No. 79-5530. Nation E. Meyer, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit for further consideration in light of Bifulco v.
United States, 447 U.S.- (1980).
No. 79–5485. Preston Sellers, et al., petitioners, v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-

ceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit granted. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of
Bifulco v. United States, 447 U.S. · (1980).
No. 79-5555. Albert Irvin Cates, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted. Judgment va-

No. 79-5584. Santos Sepulveda, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals

United States, 447 U.S. - (1980).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-980. Joseph Hampel, applicant, v. Motel Properties, Inc. The
application to stay the judgment on the Supreme Court of Georgia
addressed to Mr. Justice Marshall and referred to the Court is denied.
No. A-1056. Mahlon M. Delong, applicant, v. United States. The
application for stay of the mandate of the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fourth Circuit addressed to Mr. Justice Stevens and
referred to the Court is denied.
No. A-1079. Rudolf Wolff & Co., Ltd., applicant, v. David Neiman,
dba The London Group (1974). The application to recall and stay the
mandate of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit
addressed to Mr. Justice White and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-185. In the Matter of Disbarment of Freeman D. Mitchell.
Disbarment entered.
No. 78–1945. Universities Research Association, Inc., petitioner, v.
Stanley E. Coutu, et al. Motion of the Solicitor General for leave to
participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is granted and five
additional minutes are allotted for that purpose. The respondents
are also allotted five additional minutes for oral argument.
No. 79-408. City of Milwaukee, et al., petitioners, v. Illinois and
Michigan. Motion of Mid-America Legal Foundation for leave to file
a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Motion of National League of
Cities, et al. for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, granted.
No. 79-824. Federal Communications Commission, et al., peti-
tioners, v. WNCN Listeners Guild, et al.;

846
MONDAY, JUNE 23, 1980
No. 79-825. Insilco Broadcasting Corporation, et al., petitioners,
v. WNCN Listeners Guild, et al.;
No. 79–826. American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., et al., peti-
tioners, v. WNCN Listeners Guild, et al.; and
No. 79-827. National Association of Broadcasters, et al., petitioners,
v. WNCN Listeners Guild, et al. Motion of Washington Legal Founda-
tion for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
No. 79-838. Maine, et al., petitioners, v. Joline Thiboutot, et vir,
etc. Motion of respondents for leave to file a supplemental brief, after
argument, granted.
No. 79-1127. W. J. Estelle, Jr., Director, Texas Department of
Corrections, petitioner, v. Ernest Benjamin Smith. Motion of Ameri-
can Psychiatric Associaion for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae,
granted.
No. 79–1186. Orville E. Dennis, petitioner, v. Sidney Sparks and
R. L. Lynd, etc. Motion of American Civil Liberties Union for leave
to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
No. 79-1420. Firestone Tire & Rubber Company, petitioner, v.
John C. Risjord. Motion of respondent to supplement the record
granted.
No. 79–1893. Freedom Institute of America, et al., petitioners, v.
New Jersey. The application for release of Rev. Jerome Heinemann,
addressed to Mr. Justice Stevens and referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 79–1941. Sidney A. Diamond, Commissioner of Patents and
Trademarks, petitioner, v. John W. C. Sherwood. Motion of respondent
to expedite consideration of the petition for writ of certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 79–415. United States, petitioner, v. Andrew Kirkpatrick
Mearns III, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit denied.
No. 79–1399. Stawberry Water Users Association, et al., peti-
tioners, v. United States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Claims denied.
No. 79–1840. Jackie Wayne Scarborough, petitioner, v. United
States. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.
No. 79-6167. Robert Lee Wymore, petitioner, v. Louisiana. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana denied.

MONDAY, JUNE 23, 1980
847
No. 79-6227. Orlando Rosario, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit denied.
No. 79-6592. Vernon Wilkerson, petitioner, v. Helen Wilkerson, et
al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the District of Columbia Court
of Appeals denied.
No. 79-735. Sears, Roebuck and Co., petitioner, v. San Diego
County District Council of Carpenters. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the Supreme Court of California denied. Mr. Justice Stewart took
no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 79–1308. Fred Butterworth, Superintendent, Massachusetts
Correctional Institution at Walpole, petitioner, v. Walter J. Lovett,
Jr. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the First Circuit denied.
No. 79–1576. Jeffrey C. Miller, Acting Director, Illinois Depart-
ment of Public Aid, etc., petitioner, v. Mary Dilda, et al. Motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit denied.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, June 23, 1980, until
Wednesday, June 25, 1980.

OPINIONS
No. 78-1318. Helen B. O'Bannon, Secretary of Public Welfare,
Pennsylvania, petitioner, v. Town Court Nursing Center, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stevens. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring in the judg-
ment. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Mr. Justice Mar-
shall took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 79-616. Mohasco Corporation, petitioner, v. Ralph H. Silver.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with
whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 78-1729. United States, petitioner, v. Jack Payner. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Con-
curring opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice
Blackmun join.
No. 79–701. Roadway Express, Inc., petitioner, v. Robert E. Piper,
Jr., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit with directions
to return it to the United States District Court for the Western Dis-
trict of Louisiana for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring in part and dissenting in part.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens concurring in part and dissenting in
part. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.

MONDAY, JUNE 23, 1980
865
No. 79–343. Sun Ship, Inc., appellant, v. Pennsylvania, et al.
Appeal from the Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan.
No. 79–8. United States, petitioner, v. Herman Raddatz. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Powell concurring in part and dissenting in part. Dissent-
ing opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Brennan
and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 25, 1980
871
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell. Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
OPINIONS
No. 78–1888. Edward W. Maher, etc., petitioner, v. Virginia Gagne,
etc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell concurring in the judgment and in
Part II of the Court's opinion, with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger
and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 79-244. United States, petitioner, v. John M. Salvucci, Jr. and
Joseph G. Zackular. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the First Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom
Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
No. 79-5146. David Rawlings, petitioner, v. Kentucky. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kentucky. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun. Opinion by Mr. Justice White concurring in part with
whom Mr. Justice Stewart joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
No. 78-756. Ohio, petitioner, v. Herschel Roberts. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Ohio. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of Ohio for further proceedings not
inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom
Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Stevens join.
No. 79-5175. Randall Dale Adams, petitioner, v. Texas. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. Judgment re-
versed to the extent that it sustains the imposition of the death penalty
and case remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas for
further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Marshall concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Rehnquist. Statement by Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurring
in the judgment.
310-278 098

872
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 25, 1980
No. 79–838. Maine, et al., petitioners, v. Joline Thiboutot et vir, etc.
On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger
and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
Adjourned until Friday, June 27, 1980 at 10 o'clock.
✗

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, JUNE 27, 1980
873
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
OPINIONS
No. 79–116. Halley I. Thomas, petitioner, v. Washington Gas Light
Company, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the judgment of this Court. Mr. Justice Stevens
announced the judgment of this Court and delivered an opinion in
which Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice
Blackmun join. Opinion by Mr. Justice White concurring in the
judgment with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice
Powell join. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom
Mr. Justice Marshall joins.
No. 79–394. United States, petitioner, v. L. O. Ward, dba L. O.
Ward Oil and Gas Operations. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring
in the judgment with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 78-1177. White Mountain Apache Tribe, et al., petitioners, v.
Robert M. Bracker, et al. On writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals
of Arizona, Division One. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division One, for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with
whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Powell concurring in this case and dissenting in 78-
1604, Central Machinery Company v. Arizona State Tax Commission,
post.
No. 78–1604. Central Machinery Company, appellant, v. Arizona
State Tax Commission. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Arizona.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of
Arizona for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by
310-278 0-99

874
FRIDAY, JUNE 27, 1980
Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist, and Mr. Justice Stevens join. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell
dissenting in this case, and concurring in No. 78-1177, White Moun-
tain Apache Tribe, et al. v. Robert M. Bracker, et al., ante.
No. 79-669. Dawson Chemical Company, et al., petitioners, v. Rohm
and Haas Company. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White with
whom Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice
Stevens join. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
Adjourned until Monday, June 30, 1980 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 30, 1980
875
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Jus-
tice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice
Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 79-448. Tommy Reid, Jr., petitioner, v. Georgia. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Georgia. The petition for writ
of certiorari is granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals of Georgia for further proceedings not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Concurring opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and
Mr. Justice Blackmun join. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
No. 79–622. James Mabry, Commissioner, Arkansas Department of
Correction, petitioner, v. Francis Edward Klimas. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per
curiam. Statement by Mr. Justice Marshall concurring in the judg-
ment.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 79-1027. Edward J. King, Governor of Massachusetts, et al.,
appellants, v. Preterm, Inc., et al. Appeal from the United States
Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Appeal dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Mr. Justice Rehnquist, being of the view that the
order of the Court of Appeals "amending its mandate" to embrace
the invalidation of an entirely separate statute is not governed by
FTC v. Minneapolis-Honeywell Co., 344 U.S. 206 (1952), dissents
from dismissal of the appeal and would note probable jurisdiction and
set the case for oral argument.
310-278 0- -100

876
MONDAY, JUNE 30, 1980
No. 79-1436. Minnesota, et al., appellants, v. Planned Parenthood
of Minnesota. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr.
Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist would note probable juris-
diction and set the case for oral argument.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78–1902. International Longshoremen's Association, AFL-
CIO, petitioner, v. Consolidated Express, Inc. and Twin Express,
Inc.;
No. 78–1905. New York Shipping Association, Inc., et al., peti-
tioners, v. Consolidated Express, Inc., et al.: and
No. 79-221. Consolidated Express, Inc., et al., petitioners, v. New
York Shipping Association, Inc., et al. On petitions for writs of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.
The petitions for a writ of certiorari are granted. Judgment vacated
and cases remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit for further consideration in light of National Labor
Relations Board v. International Longshoremen's Assn., 447 U.S.—
(1980).
No. 79–393. United States, petitioner, v. Michael J. Conway. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for a writ of certiorari is granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of
United States v. Salvucci, 448 U.S.-(1980), and Rawlings v. Ken-
tucky, 448 U.S.—(1980).
No. 79-809. Michael John Grassi, Jr., petitioner, v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit. The petition for a writ of certiorari is
granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in
light of Walter v. United States, 447 U.S.-(1980).
No. 79-921. Ohio, petitioner, v. Ricardo Smith. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Ohio. The motion of re-
spondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari is granted. Judgment vacated and case.
remanded to the Supreme Court of Ohio for further consideration in
light of Ohio v. Roberts, 448 U.S.—(1980). Mr. Justice Stewart and
Mr. Justice Stevens dissent.

MONDAY, JUNE 30, 1980
877
No. 79–1242. Tiffany Construction Co., Inc., petitioner, v. Bureau
of Revenue, State of New Mexico. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the Court of Appeals of New Mexico. The petition for a writ of
certiorari is granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals of New Mexico for further consideration in light of
White Mountain Apache Tribe v. Bracker, 448 U.S.-(1980) and
Central Machinery Co. v. Arizona State Tax Commission, 448 U.S.—
(1980).
No. 79-1481. United States, petitioner, v. Louis Dickinson and
Joseph Montanino. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The motions of re-
spondents Dickinson and Montanino for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis are granted. The petition for a writ of certiorari is granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit for further consideration in light of
United States v. Salvucci, 448 U.S.— (1980).
No. 79-1677. California, petitioner, v. Nick Ramon Velasquez. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California.
The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. The petition for a writ of certiorari is granted. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court of California for
further consideration in light of Adams v. Texas, 448 U.S.-(1980).
No. 79–5026. Billy Ray Williamson, petitioner, v. Alabama;
No. 79–5301. Thomas Milton Wilson, petitioner, v. Alabama;
No. 79-5458. Edward Horsley, petitioner, v. Alabama;
No. 79-5525. Clyde Cade, petitioner, v. Alabama;
No. 79-5563. Brian Keith Baldwin, petitioner, v. Alabama;
No. 79-5709. Roger Scott Thomas, petitioner, v. Alabama;
No. 79–5741. Wayne Eugene Ritter, petitioner, v. Alabama; and
No. 79–5835. Willie Lewis Mack, petitioner, v. Alabama. On peti-
tions for writs of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Alabama. Motions
of petitioners for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petitions
for writs of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Alabama granted.
Judgments vacated and cases remanded to the Supreme Court of Ala-
bama for further consideration in light of Beck v. Alabama, 447 U.S.—
(1980).
No. 79-5804. Christopher Burroughs, petitioner, v. Georgia. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia. Mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the peti-
tion for writ of certorari granted. Judgment vacated and case re-

878
MONDAY, JUNE 30, 1980
manded to the Supreme Court of Georgia for further consideration in
light of Illinois v. Vitale, 447 U.S.—(1980).
No. 79-6150. James Michael Mathews, petitioner, v. Ohio. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Licking
County. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and the petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Licking County, for
further consideration in light of Illinois v. Vitale, 447 U.S.—(1980).
No. 79-6190. Timothy Dale Crawford, petitioner, v. Alabama. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Alabama. Mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the peti-
tion for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the Supreme Court of Alabama for further consideration in
light of Beck v. Alabama, 417 U.S.-(1980) and United States v.
Henry, 447 U.S.—(1980).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-1060. Leonard Jack Craig, applicant, v. United States Dis-
trict Court for the Northern District of California, et al. (Ford
Motor Company, Real Party In Interest). The application for stay of
trial court proceedings, addressed to Mr. Justice Brennan and referred
to the Court, is denied.
No. A-1074. Ivy P. Blue, Jr., applicant, v. Seventh District Com-
mittee of the Virginia State Bar. The application for a stay of the or-
der of the Supreme Court of Virginia (Record No. 79-1605) dated
April 18, 1980, addressed to Mr. Justice Brennan and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. A-1093. Jerome Silo, applicant, v. Thomas J. Kelly, Warden,
et al. The application for stay of trial court proceedings, addressed to
Mr. Justice Stevens, and referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 85, Original. State of Texas, plaintiff, v. State of Oklahoma. It
is ordered that John A. Carver, Jr., Esquire, of Denver, Colorado, is
appointed Special Master in this case with authority to fix the time
and conditions for the filing of additional pleadings and to direct
subsequent proceedings, and with authority to summon witnesses,
issue subpoenas, and take such evidence as may be introduced and
such as he may deem necessary to call for. The Master is directed to
submit such reports as he may deem appropriate.
The compensation of the Special Master, the allowances to him, the
compensation paid to his technical, stenographic and clerical assist-
ants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper expenses

MONDAY, JUNE 30, 1980
879
shall be charged against and be borne by the parties in such propor-
tion as the Court may hereafter direct.
It is further ordered that if the position of Special Master in this
case becomes vacant during a recess of the Court, the Chief Justice
shall have authority to make a new designation which shall have the
same effect as if originally made by the Court.
No. 79-1404. Pennhurst State School and Hospital, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Terri Lee Halderman, et al.;
No. 79–1408. Mayor of City of Philadelphia, et al., petitioners, v.
Terri Lee Halderman, et al.;
No. 79-1414. Pennsylvania Association for Retarded Citizens, et
al., petitioners, v. Pennhurst State School and Hospital, et al.;
No. 79–1415. Commissioners and Mental Health/Mental Retarda-
tion Administrators for Bucks County, et al., petitioners, v. Terri Lee
Halderman, et al.; and
No. 79–1489. Pennhurst Parents-Staff Association, petitioner, v.
Terri Lee Halderman, et al. Petitioners' motion for a stay of the
judgment of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Cir-
cuit, pending final disposition of the cases in this Court, is granted
to the extent that the judgment mandates the movement of residents
of the Pennhurst facility to "appropriate community living arange-
ments." In all other respects, the motion is denied. Mr. Justice Bren-
nan, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice
Powell would deny the motion.
No. 79-1989. Citizens Party, et al., appellants, v. A. James Man-
chin, Secretary of State, State of West Virginia. Motion of appellants
to expedite consideration of the appeal and for emergency relief is
denied.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 79-395. United States, petitioner, v. Hazel Morrison. Motion
of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The
petition for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Third Circuit is granted.
CERTIORARI DENIED

OPINIONS
No. 79–639. United States, petitioner, v. Sioux Nation of Indians,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Claims.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Opinion by
Mr. Justice White concurring in part and concurring in the judgment.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
No. 79-1268. Patricia R. Harris, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, appellant, v. Cora McRae, et al. Appeal from United States
District Court for the Eastern District of New York. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of New York for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Con-
curring opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion in this case
and in Nos. 79–4, 79–5, and 79–491, post, by Mr. Justice Brennan with
whom Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Blackmun join. Dissenting
opinion in this case and in Nos. 79-4, 79–5, and 79-491, post, by Mr.
Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion in this case and in Nos. 79–4,
79–5, and 79–491, post, by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion
in this case and in Nos. 79-4, 79-5, and 79-491, post, by Mr. Justice
Stevens.
No. 79-4. Jasper F. Williams and Eugene F. Diamond, appellants,
v. David Zbaraz, et al.;
No. 79-5. Jeffrey C. Miller, Acting Director, Illinois Department
of Public Aid, et al., appellants, v. David Zbaraz, et al.; and
No. 79-491. United States, appellant, v. David Zbaraz, et al. Ap-
peals from the United States District Court for the Northern District

908
MONDAY, JUNE 30, 1980
of Illinois. Judgment vacated and cases remanded to the United States
District Court for the Northern District of Illinois for further pro-
ceeding in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion in these cases and in No. 79-1268,
ante, by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall and
Mr. Justice Blackmun join. Dissenting opinion in these cases and in
No. 79-1268, ante, by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion in these
cases and in No. 79-1268, ante, by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting
opinion in these cases and in 79–1268, ante, by Mr. Justice Stevens.

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-1167. Walter B. Zant, Superintendent, Georgia Diagnostic
and Classification Center, applicant, v. Jack Howard Potts and the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The applica-
tion to vacate the order dated June 28, 1980 of the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit and for other relief, addressed to Mr.
Justice Powell and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice
Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision of this applica-
tion.
Adjourned until Wednesday, July 2, 1980 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, JULY 2, 1980
911
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice
White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice
Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 79-5050. William Jack Hammett, petitioner, v. Texas. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas.
Pro se motion to dismiss the petition under Rule 60 granted and peti-
tion dismissed. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins. Dissenting opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-1107. Charles Armistead, et al., appellants, v. Associated
General Contractors of California, et al.;
No. 78–1108. City of Los Angeles, et al., appellants, v. Associated
General Contractors of California, et al.;
No. 78–1114. Los Angeles County, et al., appellants, v. Associated
General Contractors of California, et al.;
No. 78–1382. Philip M. Klutznick, Secretary of Commerce, appel-
lant, v. Associated General Contractors of California, et al.; and
No. 78-1442. National Association for the Advancement of Colored
People, etc., appellant, v. Associated General Contractors of Cali-
fornia, et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the
Central District of California. Judgment vacated and cases remanded
to the United States District Court for the Central District of Cali-
fornia for further consideration in light of Fullilove v. Klutznick,
448 U.S. (1980). Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice Rehnquist,
and Mr. Justice Stevens would affirm the judgment.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 79–1631. Democratic Party of the United States of America,
et al., appellants, v. Bronson C. La Follette, et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Wisconsin. In this case probable jurisdiction is
310-278 0-103

912
WEDNESDAY, JULY 2, 1980
noted. The judgment of the Supreme Court of Wisconsin, filed Janu-
ary 19, 1980, is stayed pending the issuance of the mandate of this
Court.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 78-918. Republic Steel Corporation, petitioner. v. Occupational
Safety and Health Administration, et al.; and
No. 78-919. American Iron and Steel Institute. et al., petitioners, v.
Occupational Safety and Health Administration, et al. Motion of
American Petroleum Institute. et al. for leave to file a brief, as amici
curiae, in No. 78-919 is granted. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit granted. The
cases are consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral
argument.
No. 79–1213. Wayne Minnick, et al., petitioners, v. California De-
partment of Corrections, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate District. granted.
No. 79-1356. Kathy Sue Johnson, et al., petitioners, v. Board of
Education of the City of Chicago. et al. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit
granted.
No. 79-1601. George Sumner, Warden, petitioner. v. Robert Mata.
Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit granted.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 79-489. Mario Merola. petitioner, v. Howard E. Bell and Rob-
ert Davis; and
No. 79-561. New York News Inc., petitioner, v. Howard E. Bell,
Justice, Supreme Court of New York, et al. Petitions for writs of cer-
tiorari to the Court of Appeals of New York denied. Mr. Justice Bren-
nan. Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Blackmun would grant
certiorari.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 78-986. Arkansas Louisiana Gas Company. petitioner, c. Frank
J. Hall. et al. Petition for rehearing denied. Mr. Justice Stewart took
no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 79–901. Ohio, petitioner, v. Donald L. Korn;
No. 79–1216. Lawrence J. Syrovatka, et ux., petitioners, v. Eldin
J. Ehrlich, etc., et al.;

913

OPINIONS
No. 78-911. Industrial Union Department, AFL-CIO, petitioner,
v. American Petroleum Institute, et al.; and
No. 78-1036. Ray Marshall, Secretary of Labor, petitioner, v.
American Petroleum Institute, et al. On writs of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Mr. Justice Stevens announced the judgment of the Court
and delivered an opinion in which Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr.
Justice Stewart join and in Parts I, II, III-A-C and E of which Mr.
Justice Powell joins. Concurring opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell concurring in part and in the judgment.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist concurring in the judgment. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Bren-
nan, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Blackmun join.
No. 78-1007. H. Earl Fullilove, et al., petitioners, v. Philip M.
Klutznick, Secretary of Commerce of the United States, et al. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Chief Justice Burger announced the
judgment of the Court and delivered an opinion in which Mr. Justice
White and Mr. Justice Powell join. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice
Powell. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall concurring in the judgment
with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Blackmun join. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 79-243. Richmond Newspapers, Inc., et al., appellants, v. Vir-
ginia, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
granted. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court

914
WEDNESDAY, JULY 2, 1980
of Virginia for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion
of this Court. Mr. Chief Justice Burger announced the judgment of
the Court and delivered an opinion in which Mr. Justice White and
Mr. Justice Stevens join. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice White.
Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Brenan concurring in the judgment with whom Mr. Justice Marshall
joins. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart concurring in the judgment.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring in the judgment. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Mr. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
The Chief Justice said:
66
"All cases submitted, and all other matters before the Court which
were ready for disposition, have been acted on by the Court. Accord-
ingly, it is ordered that all cases remaining on the docket, but not ready
for consideration, are hereby continued to the session of the Court be-
ginning the first Monday in October.
The Court is adjourned to the first Monday in October, 1980, at
which time the October 1979 Term will end.
The October 1980 Term of the Court will begin as provided by stat-
ute, on the first Monday in October.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-1135. Railway Labor Executives' Association, applicant, v.
William M. Gibbons, Trustee ; Continental Illinois National Bank and
Trust Company of Chicago, et al. The application for stay of the pre-
liminary injunction entered by the United States District Court for
the Northern District of Illinois (No. 75 B 2697), entered June 9, 1980,
is denied. Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist would grant the application. Mr. Justice Brennan took no
part in the consideration or decision of this application.
No. A-1168. Philip M. Klutznick, Secretary of Commerce, et al.,
applicants, v. Control Data Corporation, et al. The application of the
Solicitor General to vacate the order of the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the District of Columbia Circuit (No. 80-1143), entered
June 24, 1980, is granted. Mr. Justice Brennan dissents. Mr. Chief
Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Stevens took no
part in the consideration or decision of this application.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 17, 1980
1021
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
REHEARINGS DENIED
Na. 79-4. Jasper F. Williams and Eugene F. Diamond, appellants
v. David Zbaraz, et al.;
No. 79-5. Jeffrey C. Miller, Acting Director, Illinois Department
of Public Aid, et al., appellants, v. David Zbaraz, et al.;
No. 79-491. United States, appellant, v. David Zbaraz, et al.; and
No. 79–1268. Patricia R. Harris, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, appellant, v. Cora McRae, et al. The motion of Richard Abel,
et al. for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted. The motion of
the Abortion Rights Council of Minnesota, et al. for leave to file a
brief, as amici curiae, is granted. Petitions for rehearing denied.
No. 79-561. New York News, Inc., petitioner, v. Howard E. Bell,
Justice, Supreme Court of New York, et al.;
No. 79–669. Dawson Chemical Company, et al., petitioners, v. Rohm
and Haas Company;
No. 79-1615. Grover C. Hall, appellant, v. California, et al.;
No. 79–1634. Robert Starr, et al., petitioners, v. Richard Nixon,
et al.;
No. 79–1714. Jimmie Alexander, petitioner, v. Los Angeles County
Civil Service Commission, et al.;
No. 79–6099. Joseph Blaine Starvaggi, petitioner, v. Texas; and
No. 79–6350. Margie Velma Barfield, petitioner, v. North Carolina.
Petitions for rehearing denied.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 18, 1980
1037
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 80–182. Anthony J. Celebrezze, Jr., Secretary of State of Ohio,
petitioner, v. John B. Anderson, et al. The renewed motion of peti-
tioner to expedite consideration of the petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist would grant
the petition and set the case for oral argument during the week of
October 6, 1980.
